results: – Egyptian police fired tear gas and water cannons into the streets of Cairo and elsewhere today to try to stop another day of massive anti-government protests. At least five people were killed and more than 100 injured as police used tear gas, batons, and water cannons to try to disperse demonstrators, reports CNN. The protests, inspired by the ones in Tunisia, are the biggest in years and have brought tens of thousands to the streets in cities around the country. Opposition leader Mohamed ElBaradei has called for a million people to take to the streets tomorrow, and has called for President Hosni Mubarak to step down immediately, reports AP.

– Egypt's Hosni Mubarak delivered a televised address at midnight local time today in which he called for calm and asked the people to keep peaceful protests, reports CNN. Mubarak then announced that he had asked his government to resign. "We all honestly should stand with each other for this country," he said. Click here for more on the speech and the protests.

– Egypt's government has ordered the closure of al-Jazeera's office in Cairo and all of its affiliates, CNN reports. The move comes after the network reported that the army had been deployed on the streets. Al-Jazeera's English-language channel has also been shut down, but al-Jazeera's network in Egypt has not been affected. Al-Jazeera's offices in Cairo have been closed since yesterday, according to the network's website.

– Opposition leader Mohamed ElBaradei has called for a "million-man march" in Egypt's Tahrir Square tomorrow to demand the resignation of Hosni Mubarak, who has vowed to stay in power until at least September. "This is a historic day in the history of Egypt, the day when the people will reject the dictatorship," he said in a televised address to the nation, according to al-Jazeera. ElBaradei's call for a million people to take to the streets comes as clashes between pro-Mubarak supporters and anti-Mubarak protesters raged for a fifth day, reports CNN. At least two people were killed as police fired tear gas and rubber bullets in an attempt to stop demonstrators from reaching a central square that has become the epicenter of the protests.
– It's that time of the year again, when we take a look back at some of the best movies and TV shows of the season so far. Some of the best movies of the first half of the season:

– Algeria's president announced today that he will lift the country's state of emergency, which has been in place for nearly 20 years, CNN reports. President Abdelaziz Bouteflika made the announcement after thousands of protesters took to the streets again in the wake of Tunisia's ouster. "The state of emergency will be lifted in the very close future," Bouteflika said, according to al-Jazeera. The move comes after protesters called for the end of the emergency earlier this week.

– Google's top executive in Egypt has been released by the government after more than a week in custody, CNN reports. The executive, Wael Ghonim, was arrested on Jan. 29 and accused of inciting violence at anti-Mubarak protests, but his whereabouts were unknown until today. "We can confirm that Wael Ghonim has been released in the hands of the Egyptian government," a Google spokesperson said in a statement, according to the Wall Street Journal.

– Google exec Wael Ghonim, one of the stars of the protests in Egypt, gave an emotional interview to CNN today, saying that he’s “ready to die” for change. “This country is our country,” he said, adding that he’s not sure whether Hosni Mubarak will leave office, but that he’s “ready to die” for it. “This is a new day in Egypt,” he said. “This is a new day in Egypt. This is a new Egypt. This is the country that we live in. This is the country that we call home. This is the country that we call home. This is the country that we want to live in. This is the country that we want to rule. This is the country that we want to live in.”

– Opposition leader Mohammed ElBaradei has a message for Hosni Mubarak: It's time for you to go. In an interview with CNN's Wolf Blitzer, ElBaradei called for the army to take control of the country and end the state of emergency that has been in place since Mubarak took power 30 years ago. "I think it's time for him to go," said ElBaradei. "He has been a friend of our country for 30 years. It's time for him to leave." Blitzer asked ElBaradei what he would say to Mubarak, to which ElBaradei replied, "I think it's time for you to go." Click here for more on ElBaradei's interview.

– The Washington Post has a front-page story today on Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, the two mortgage giants at the center of the financial crisis. The story focuses on the plight of low- and moderate-income families hit hard by the collapse of the housing market, including a 4-year-old girl whose pre-K classroom was turned into a mobile home by a government-backed charity.

A new report from the Federal Reserve Bank of New York finds that only about half of the country's private-sector retirement plans are actually invested in the stock market, and that only about one-third of those investments are actually profitable. That's according to an analysis of public records going back to 1999. The New York Times reports that the number of private-sector retirement plans that are actually invested in the stock market is actually higher than the number of private-sector workers who are actually invested in the stock market. – When President Obama named Hank Paulson as his Treasury secretary two years ago, he said he wanted to "keep the seat warm" and keep Goldman Sachs at the top of the game. Well, now that he's at the Treasury, he says he wants to keep Goldman Sachs at the top of the game, too, reports the Wall Street Journal.

– Henry Blodget's Wall Street Journal op-ed has gotten quite a bit of attention lately. Here's a sampling: Blodget: "It seems to me that the market is not really free if oil companies get huge tax breaks and financial institutions such as Fannie Mae, Freddie Mac and AIG know that the federal government will bail them out when they make stupid decisions." Blodget: "I thank the treasury secretary, Hank Paulson, Federal Reserve Chairman Ben Bernanke, and SEC Chairman Chris Cox for joining me today. This is a pivotal moment for America's economy." Blodget: "It is not just that Merrill Lynch agreed to be purchased by Bank of America or that the legendary investment bank Lehman Brothers filed for bankruptcy or that the insurance giant AIG is floundering. ... US Wall Street as we know it is kaput. ... The markets have only just begun to force some financial discipline on the majority of US lawmakers left on the sidelines as Fed and Treasury make rapid—fire decisions in recent days, leaving Capitol Hill lawmakers effectively impotent—and frustrated."

– The Wall Street Journal's editorial board thinks President Bush's 700-billion-dollar plan to revive the US economy is a lousy idea, and they're calling on Bush to veto it. The board says the plan doesn't go far enough in tackling the financial crisis, and they're calling on Bush to veto it because it doesn't go far enough in addressing the root causes of the crisis, reports the New York Times. (Read the full column here.) The editors say the plan doesn't go far enough to fix the economy, and they're calling on Bush to veto it because it doesn't go far enough in addressing the root causes of the crisis.

– Barack Obama and John McCain are due to meet for their first debate tonight, and both candidates are calling for the event to be delayed—but Obama is resisting McCain's call, the Wall Street Journal reports. The candidates will meet at Hofstra University in New York at 9pm.

– Citigroup's purchase of Wachovia is good news for Wall Street, but it's not great news for ordinary Americans, writes David Leonhardt at the New York Times. Citigroup's purchase of Wachovia raises the stakes in the financial crisis, but it's not enough to change the fundamental problem: "Too many people do not understand the seriousness of the situation," writes Leonhardt. "What we are witnessing, in the broadest sense and in the broadest sense of modern economics, is the bankruptcy of modern economics. Its conceit has been that we had solved the problem of stability. The basic problem here is that too many people do not understand the seriousness of the situation." Click here for Leonhardt's full column.

– Charles Krauthammer isn't happy with Henry Paulson's response to the financial crisis, and he's not happy with President Obama's either. In an op-ed in the Washington Post, Krauthammer calls for "substantial new oversight" of the Treasury Department, which he says "seemingly requires giving the Treasury secretary nearly a trillion dollars and extraordinary latitude to pick winners and losers." Krauthammer also takes issue with the Bush administration's plan to let Wall Street gamble with the taxpayer's money, calling it an "absurd giveaway" to investors.

– World Bank President Robert B. Zoellick says the financial system may have reached a "tipping point" and it's time for governments to step in to prop up confidence, reports the Wall Street Journal. "If governments don't step in, the situation could get much worse," Zoellick said in an interview with the Journal's MarketBeat blog. "It's going to be very difficult for us to recover from this."

– The stock market's prolonged tumble has wiped out about $2 trillion in Americans' retirement savings in the past 15 months, a blow that could force workers to stay on the job longer than planned, rein in spending and possibly further stall an economy reliant on consumer dollars, Congress' top budget analyst said yesterday. For many Americans, pensions, and 401 (k) plans are their only form of savings, the Washington Post reports. The financial crisis has gone global. Stock indexes have fallen and credit markets are seizing up around the world Get Wonkbook delivered to your inbox and mobile device every morning.

– Treasury Secretary Hank Paulson is taking a drubbing from pundits for his handling of the financial crisis. “The truth is we were going to have a serious financial crisis no matter what Paulson did or did n’t do, thanks to the incredible ineptitude of Wall Street and the nation’s financial regulators over the past few years,” Charles Krauthammer writes in the Washington Post. “Now, what was that about Hank Paulson having blown it? How he foolishly let Lehman Brothers go under and started a chain reaction that quickly turned into a financial meltdown?” “He was so focused on his cockamamie plan to buy up distressed mortgages and mortgage—backed securities, instead of injecting capital into banks in exchange for shares,” Krauthammer continues. “How he and the other finance ministers were so way behind the curve this past weekend in failing to come up with a detailed and coordinated plan to restore confidence in financial markets?”

– If you’re worried about your investments, you might want to stop reading now. Here’s what you need to know about the current financial crisis, and what you can do about it, courtesy of the Wall Street Journal, the New York Times, and the Washington Post.

– In the wake of the financial crisis, some are calling for a new Bretton Woods summit, modeled after the 1944 gathering that helped prevent a repeat of the Great Depression. The Europeans have pressed successfully for a new Bretton Woods summit, modeled after the 1944 gathering that inoculated the world against a repeat of the Great Depression, the Washington Post reports.

– If you’re looking for a scapegoat to blame for the financial crisis, look no further than Wall Street. Many Republican members of Congress say the meltdown would not have been as bad if not for the “ baleful impact” of accounting rules, Politico reports. John McCain, for example, says the meltdown “would not be nearly as bad as it is but for the baleful impact” of accounting rules.

– Oil prices have plunged to their lowest level in more than two years as the global financial crisis takes a heavy toll on world demand, and Iran is scrambling to find alternative energy sources, reports the Wall Street Journal.

– The Wall Street Journal is out with a scathing analysis of President Obama's economic strategy—and it doesn't sound very friendly to his chances of winning re-election. The story, headlined "Obama's Plan Isn't Working," notes that the president's deficit-reduction plan "has little chance of succeeding" because it focuses too much on tax cuts for the rich and not enough on infrastructure spending.

– Brazil's president-elect, Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva, says the nation's economic crisis must not wait until he takes office next month. Further legislation to deal with the economic crisis should not wait until the new president takes office, he said in an interview with the Wall Street Journal. "Fortunately, the president-elect will be a senator and can propose legislation without waiting to be sworn in as president Brazil's Auto Industry Feels Impact of Financial Crisis"

– President Obama and other world leaders gather in Washington today for a two-day summit to discuss solutions to the global financial crisis. Here's what you need to know: Brazil's president, Luiz In cio Lula da Silva, said developing countries must be given a greater role in solving the crisis, the Wall Street Journal reports. He called for action to prevent a repeat of the current crisis. The US needs to take aggressive action to solve the crisis, he said. “If we don’t act now, the consequences will be catastrophic,” he said. “We must act now to prevent a repeat of this crisis.”

– President Bush and other leaders from the world's biggest economies are meeting in Washington today for the G20, an emergency summit created in response to the global financial crisis. “This is a decisive moment for the global economy,” Bush said yesterday. “It’s the most decisive moment for American-style capitalism since July 1944, when the leaders of 44 nations emerged from a remote lodge in the White Mountains of New Hampshire with the blueprint for a new world financial order based on the principles of free markets, free trade, and the free flow of capital.” In the Washington Post, Max Fisher thinks the summit could be a good thing. After years of G-7 and G-8 meetings, the new G20 format will give most of the key emerging economies seats at the world's top table. The summit could be even better if it spurs governments to pass stimulus packages.

– The chiefs of the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund have declined to participate in a major conference on the global financial crisis that will be held in Washington next month, the Washington Post reports. World Bank President Robert Zoellick and IMF chief Dominique Strauss-Kahn will speak at the conference, but neither will take part in a Q&A session with reporters afterward.

– Iceland's prime minister resigned today, as the island nation's currency tanked and protesters took to the streets to demand new elections, the AP reports. Prime Minister Sigmundur David Gunnlaugsson announced his resignation in a televised address, saying he had no choice but to step down because his government couldn't carry out the country's "national task" in the face of the crisis caused by the collapse of the national currency. Gunnlaugsson's resignation is expected to be accepted by the country's president, who has the power to dissolve the parliament and call new elections. Iceland's central bank estimates the country's current account deficit, which hit a record high of $22 billion last year, will reach $48 billion this year, the BBC reports. The collapse of the national currency, which hit an all-time low of 3 against the dollar earlier this year, has made the island nation an international destination for shopping, as well as for traditional tourism. Icelanders have been protesting outside the parliament in Reykjavik, demanding elections for a new government.

– France has unveiled a $33 billion economic stimulus plan that includes cash payments to the poor, a bigger rebate on new—car purchases and a speedup in high-cost public works projects, the Wall Street Journal reports. The plan, which the government says is needed to combat the effects of the global financial crisis, also includes tax breaks for businesses and a boost in infrastructure spending.

– The leaders of Argentina, Brazil, Chile, and Paraguay are meeting in Rio de Janeiro today to discuss ways of stepping up economic cooperation in the face of the global financial crisis, the AP reports. Brazil's President Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva, Argentina's President Cristina Kirchner, and Paraguay's President Michel Temer are expected to sign an agreement on economic and financial cooperation. It's not clear how much the agreement will cost or how quickly it will be finalized.

– Health officials around the world are scrambling to contain the spread of swine flu, which has now killed at least 100 people in Mexico and may have killed as many as 159 in the US. In Mexico, where the outbreak began, public gatherings have been canceled and schools and businesses have been forced to close, the AP reports. Canada has reported its first human case, a tourist who returned from a trip to Mexico last week. The World Health Organization has raised its alert level from three to four, the BBC reports. Britain has confirmed two cases of the disease and is sending samples of the virus to a government lab for testing.

– Mexico’s ambassador to China says he was denied access to a hotel where many Mexicans are being quarantined because he’s a Mexican citizen. China has denied discriminating against Mexicans, but the row is growing, the AP reports. Many Mexicans have been quarantined in mainland China since the virus was found in a Mexican man in Hong Kong. More than 100 people, including many Mexicans, have been quarantined in mainland China since the virus was found in a Mexican man in Hong Kong Eateries in Mexico City are to reopen today after the country recorded a fall in new cases of the swine flu virus. Libraries, museums, and churches are to follow suit a day later but cinemas, theaters, and bars are to remain closed.

– The number of confirmed cases of swine flu in the US has risen to 176, the World Health Organization announced today. Most of the new cases are in New York, California, Ohio, Texas, and Massachusetts. In Mexico, the death toll has risen to 160 and the country has begun a five-day shutdown of much of its economy, the BBC reports. In Hong Kong, where China's first case of swine flu was confirmed, 300 people have been quarantined at a hotel where a guest from Mexico stayed.

– In the wake of the Orlando shooting, President Obama is calling for an independent commission to look into what happened at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School in Parkland, Fla., where 17 students and teachers died in a shooting rampage. “What happened at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School is a tragedy, and we must do everything in our power to prevent such tragedies from happening in the future,” Obama said in a statement released by the White House. “No one deserves to be killed or injured at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School, and we will do everything in our power to prevent that from happening.”

– When Ros Atkins, a BBC radio presenter, came back to the UK after working in Mexico City, family and friends avoided him like he had, well, swine flu. After reading his account, we wondered about others who have visited Mexico recently and experienced the same sort of reaction upon returning home

– Health officials around the world are scrambling to contain the spread of swine flu, which has now killed at least 81 people in Mexico. The World Health Organization has raised its pandemic alert to phase 5, the highest level, and warned that the disease has the potential to become a global pandemic, the AP reports. Britain has seen its first case, a British Airways cabin steward who fell ill on a flight from Mexico City to London. He is being treated in an isolation unit at a London hospital. Click here for more on the swine flu outbreak.

– The swine flu outbreak has exposed the meat industry’s “monumental power,” Christopher de Bellaigue writes in the Guardian. “The initial outbreaks across North America reveal an infection already traveling at higher velocity than did the last official pandemic strain, the 1968 Hong Kong flu Professionals may be better prepared to deal with a pandemic.” The crisis “should alert us to a highly globalised industry with global political clout,” de Bellaigue writes, but “it does n't mean we are safe.” For more on the outbreak, click here.

– Scientists in Hong Kong and the US say they've discovered a synthetic compound that could stop the spread of bird flu and other flu strains. The compound, which has not been tested on humans, appears to be able to stop the spread of the H5N1 bird flu virus, as well as other flu strains, including the H1N1 seasonal flu virus, the Wall Street Journal reports. Such drugs, like oseltamivir, have been largely useless against flu strains like the H1N1 seasonal flu virus.

– Two children in California have tested positive for a new strain of swine flu, making them the first in the US to get the illness outside of lab tests, reports the Los Angeles Times. One of the kids, a 10-year-old boy, tested positive for the H1N1 virus after returning home from a spring break trip to Mexico. The other, a 4-year-old boy, tested positive for the virus after returning home from a school trip to Texas. Both children have recovered and are in stable condition at a Los Angeles children's hospital, reports the San Francisco Chronicle.

– If the swine flu outbreak turns into a global pandemic, Asia will be ready, a Chinese virologist warns. "We are counting down to a pandemic," Guan Yi, who helped trace the 2003 outbreak of SARS, tells Reuters. "The most populous countries in Asia, China and India, will be ill—prepared to handle." In other swine flu news: Health officials in Ohio have confirmed the state's first case, a 2-year-old boy who recently returned from Mexico, the AP reports. The boy recently returned from a trip to Mexico, where the first case of the H1N1 virus was detected. In Mexico, the death toll from the virus has risen to 149, and the World Health Organization has raised its alert level to phase 5, the most severe level. The US has now confirmed 19 cases, including 8 in New York, 7 in California, and 3 in Texas, reports the Wall Street Journal.

– The toddler who became the first death outside of Mexico from H1N1 has become the youngest person ever to die with the disease outside of Mexico. The child, a 23-month-old boy who visited Mexico with his family, died yesterday in Texas, reports the AP. The boy, who lived in Brownsville, had recently returned from a trip to Cancun, where H1N1 has now infected 1,600 people. In other swine flu news, Egypt has ordered the cull of all the country's pigs. Google searches for flu in Mexico spiked last week even before the outbreak was widely known, reports the Chicago Tribune.

– The owner of a New York City hotel that was quarantined after a Mexican guest tested positive for H1N1 is suing the city, the NYPD, and the CDC, accusing them of “reckless and unethical” behavior, the New York Daily News reports. “I am suing the City of New York, the Department of Health, the NYPD, the CDC, and all who participated in the quarantine of my hotel,” says Thomas Prendergast. “I am also suing the owners of the Metropark Hotel in Hong Kong, who did not follow proper procedures in placing me in quarantine.” For more on the swine flu outbreak, click here.

– Two journalists working for Reuters are dead after being ambushed in Baghdad, the news agency says. Haider Kadhem and Waleed Khaled were on their way to cover a shootout between police and gunmen when their vehicle was stopped by gunmen who opened fire on them. Witnesses say the journalists were riddled with bullets as they tried to flee the scene.

– A new wave of political bloggers is challenging Britain's old media pundits—but who are they and which ones matter? Oliver Burkeman, writing for the Guardian, takes an in-depth look at them. Among them are Perry de Havilland and Justin McKeating, both of whom are writing for the Telegraph.

– A 21-year-old German man committed suicide today by leaping from a fourth-floor balcony of his London apartment, the Telegraph reports. Steffen Andersch was a singer, guitarist, activist, and photographer who struggled with depression.
– The author of the best-selling history of the Middle East, The Great War for Civilization, has died at the age of 91, reports the Telegraph.

– British PM David Cameron has apologized for his country's handling of the Iraq war, saying that "mistakes were made" but that the situation is "under control," the Telegraph reports. "I apologize to the people of this country for any confusion that may have been caused as a result of the mistakes of the last few weeks," he said. "We are on the right track and we will continue to be on the right track."

– Iraq's prime minister has announced that the country's armed forces are fully capable of taking over the country's cities and towns after eight years of war. Nouri al-Maliki made the announcement at a joint press conference with President Nouri al-Maliki. "The armed forces are ready to take over the cities and towns of Anbar, Fallujah, Ramadi, Fallujah, and Dohuk," said Nouri al-Maliki. "We are confident that the Iraqis will be able to handle the situation on their own," he said.

– Dick Cheney has made it clear that he's not happy with the Obama administration's handling of the Iraq war, and he plans to raise it with British Prime Minister David Cameron when he visits the UK this week, the Washington Post reports. "I will raise with the prime minister my concerns about the conduct of the United States troops in Iraq," Cheney said in an interview with the Daily Mail. "I will also raise my concerns about the fairness of the process by which the United States has tried to transition from Iraq to Afghanistan. And I will raise my concerns about the fairness of the fairness of the process by which the United States has tried to sell us weapons of mass destruction. And I will raise my concerns with the prime minister about the fairness of the process by which the United States has tried to sell us weapons of mass destruction."

– British PM David Cameron is calling for an immediate review of the country's response to the 2004 Indian Ocean tsunami that left more than 220,000 people dead or missing—and the country's status as one of the world's most bombed-out nations, the Telegraph reports. "There has never been a moment like it on British television," he said at an event marking the fifth anniversary of the disaster.
– Michael Howard's latest movie is an anti-war satire called Turtles Can Fly, and the director talks to the Los Angeles Times about what makes it so anti-war.

– George W. Bush will be sworn in as the 45th president of the United States tomorrow—and if he doesn't win reelection, it will be the first time since John F. Kennedy was president that the nation doesn't have a Republican in the White House, the Wall Street Journal reports. "This will be one of the biggest parties in American history, but half of the country will be left out," said RNC chairman Reince Priebus.

– Saddam Hussein's regime destroyed weapons years before the US invasion of Iraq, according to an Iraq Survey Group report released yesterday. The report found that the dictator's regime destroyed weapons of mass destruction years before the US invasion of Iraq, the Los Angeles Times reports. The US investigators searching for Saddam's alleged weapons of mass destruction have given up the hunt and left Iraq with an appeal to the Pentagon for the release of several Iraqi scientists still being questioned.
– Iraq has handed over control of the ruins of Babylon to the country’s archaeology department, ending a battle that began when US troops desecrated the site in 2005, the Telegraph reports.

– Two American soldiers have been charged with premeditated murder in the slaying of an Iraqi police officer, CNN reports. According to police, 24-year-old Lt. 1st Class Joseph O’Brien allegedly shot the officer five times in the back of the head as he lay on the ground with his hands tied behind his back. O’Brien’s body was found yesterday in the garage of the police headquarters where he worked in Tikrit.

– British prosecutors are looking into nine new allegations of abuse against soldiers in Iraq, the Guardian reports. The allegations revolve around two separate incidents last year—one involving the rape of an Iraqi woman, and another involving the beating of a man whose body was found in a canal.
– Richard Gere’s much-anticipated role as Bafta-winning singer Bafta Arab cinema weekend arrives today—and if you’re wondering what’s in store for him, we’ve got news for you.

– As the world watches to see whether President Obama will seek re-election, CNN takes a look at some of the big-name candidates who haven't been around long enough to have an impact on the race. Among them are Sarah Palin, Mitt Romney, and Barack Obama.

– Al-Jazeera is the fifth most influential brand in the world, behind Apple and Google, according to a survey by a worldwide branding consultancy. Al-Jazeera is the fifth most influential brand in the world, behind Apple and Google, in a survey by a worldwide branding consultancy. – In the wake of the Boston Marathon bombing, President Obama called for an end to the use of weapons of mass destruction in Iraq and Afghanistan. Now the White House is calling for Congress to pass legislation that would ban the use of weapons of mass destruction there, CNN reports.

– The head of the UN oil program in Iraq and a senior UN official who dealt with contracts for the program have been suspended following an independent investigation that accused them of misconduct, a UN spokesman said yesterday.

– CNN's top news executive has quit abruptly after 23 years following claims he accused US forces of deliberately targeting journalists in Iraq. Jeff Zucker announced his resignation as president and chief executive of CNN and MSNBC yesterday.

– American soldiers traumatized by fighting in Iraq and Afghanistan are to be offered the drug ecstasy to help free them of flashbacks and recurring nightmares, the Telegraph reports. Photographs of detainees being sexually humiliated at Abu Ghraib are to be offered the drug to help free them of flashbacks and recurring nightmares.

– Ukraine wants to join NATO, President Viktor Yushchenko told George Bush today at the alliance's summit in Brussels. The former Soviet nation wants "to become a member of the transatlantic organization," Yushchenko said, according to the Wall Street Journal.

– Britain's attorney general has concluded that the US-led invasion of Iraq was illegal because it did not comply with international standards for self-defense, the Telegraph reports. "There is no justification for launching an invasion of Iraq that does not comply with international standards for self-defense," Lord Goldsmith wrote in his legal opinion.

– US officials are investigating the kidnapping of an Italian journalist in Iraq, CNN reports. According to reports, US troops opened fire on Stefanie Glaviano, 32, as she walked back to her car after being abducted, and killed one of her rescuers. Glaviano, an award-winning journalist, was working for al-Jazeera when she was seized on March 6.

– A former detainee at Abu Ghraib is suing the US military over the abuse he suffered at the hands of American troops, the Telegraph reports. In the lawsuit filed in US District Court for the Southern District of New York, the man says he was beaten, starved, deprived of food and water, forced to watch videos of fellow inmates being abused, and made to watch videos of rape and beatings—all while being held in solitary confinement.

– The Senate Intelligence Committee has wrapped up an investigation into President Obama's Mideast policy—and found no evidence that the White House tried to mislead Congress, the Washington Post reports. “There was no attempt to mislead Congress,” committee chair Dianne Feinstein said. “There was no attempt to mislead the American people.”

– A 25-year-old British soldier has become the first living recipient of the nation's highest award for bravery since the Falklands War. Private Johnson Beharry, who risked his life to save fellow soldiers during an ambush in Iraq, received the Victoria Cross last week, the Telegraph reports. Beharry is the first British soldier to receive the award since the 1982 Falklands War.

– A British newspaper has printed an incendiary front-page editorial criticizing Prime Minister Tony Blair’s role in the Iraq war, the Telegraph reports. “I’ll hold Blair to account,” writes Reg Keys, whose son was killed in Iraq. “The war was illegal and immoral.”

– US troops in Iraq used some 29 interrogation techniques that were approved by the highest-ranking US general in the country, including sleep manipulation, stress positions, and the use of dogs to exploit Arab fears, according to documents obtained by the Washington Post.
– The Guardian takes a look at Paul Wolfowitz's bid to be the next head of the World Bank—and finds that he doesn't exactly have an easy time of it.

– Iraq has a new president—and a new prime minister. Nouri al-Maliki has named Jalal Talabani as the country’s new president, ending the country’s two-month political deadlock, the Telegraph reports. Talabani, the Kurd leader, will serve a four-year term as president, while Nouri al-Maliki will serve a two-year term as prime minister.

– Baghdad's iconic Green Zone has been transformed into what some are calling the "hippest" district in the Iraqi capital—the "hippest district," in the words of the New York Times. Residents are emerging from the Green Zone's narrow, tree-lined streets with bright yellows, reds, and purples to celebrate the city's history, culture, and art scene, the Times reports. "It's the hippest district in Baghdad, it's the hippest district in the country, it's the hippest district in the world," says one resident.

– British soldiers are deserting the army at an alarming rate, with more than 2,000 deserting so far this year—an increase of more than 300% over the same period last year, the Telegraph reports. Many are either deserting the army or going absent without leave.

– As Britain celebrates the 60th anniversary of the end of World War II, the Telegraph takes a look back at how young people around the country reacted to the conflict—and what they think we should do about it.

– Al-Jazeera has closed its offices in Tehran, accusing the Iranian government of inflaming ethnic riots in the south of the country. Al-Jazeera has also cut ties with CNN and Al-Jazeera English, the AP reports.

– Britain's attorney general told Tony Blair the invasion of Iraq was legal less than two weeks before it took place because the UN had already approved it, according to 13 pages of confidential legal advice leaked to the Guardian today. Lord Goldsmith said that even without a second resolution from the Security Council, the invasion was legal because of the threat of weapons of mass destruction.

– Women are already serving on the front lines in Iraq and Afghanistan—and the US military may soon allow them to do the same. Defense Secretary Robert Gates told Meet the Press today that the Pentagon is looking into allowing female soldiers to serve on the front lines, the Telegraph reports.

– British Prime Minister David Cameron has ordered an investigation into the death of an Italian intelligence officer shot dead by US troops in Iraq in 2005, the Telegraph reports. Italy's foreign minister has called for an inquiry into the officer's death, which the US military has blamed on hostile action.

– British Prime Minister Tony Blair has finally apologized for his country’s role in the Iraq war, the Telegraph reports. “I am truly sorry for what has happened,” Blair said in an interview with the Daily Mail. “What we did was wrong, and I apologize for that.”

– The chief of Britain's MI6 is accused of trying to seduce the body tasked with finding Saddam Hussein's weapons of mass destruction in Iraq. Dr Rod Barton, a former senior weapons inspector in Iraq, says MI6 chief Sir John Scarlett and a top Ministry of Defense official intervened in a report by the Iraq Survey Group early last year, the Telegraph reports. Barton tells the Daily Mail that Scarlett and the official asked him to change the report's language to make it appear that the weapons were never found.

– Left-wing British MP George Galloway has made a name for himself in political circles by railing against the US war in Iraq and supporting anti-war protesters in his native Scotland, the Telegraph reports. His latest controversy centers around allegations that he profited from illegal oil deals in Iraq—and that American companies helped cover them up. "Whatever else you made of him, when it came to delivering sustained barrages of political invective, you had to salute his indefatigability Sparks fly in Washington, but doubts remain," writes the Daily Record in a blistering editorial today.

– George W. Bush has weighed in on the uproar over leaked photos of Saddam Hussein in his underwear, calling for an investigation into how the pictures ended up in the public domain, the Telegraph reports.

– It's not the kind of headline you'd expect to read on the front page of the New York Times, but that's exactly what happened in this case. An anonymous source tells the paper that French authorities have raided the home of Jean-Pierre Jeunet, founder of the ber-Gte restaurant chain and one of the world's most high-profile purveyors of fine food. Police say Jeunet's ex-wife, fellow ber-Gte executive Jean-Pierre Jeunet, and two of her friends were found dead inside the home, and that investigators are trying to determine if foul play is suspected.

– Malaysia's Mahathir Mohamad has lashed out at the US, calling George W. Bush a "rogue regime" bent on "terrorizing innocent civilians," the Telegraph reports. He also said he was disappointed that Tony Blair—who joined the US invasion of Iraq—has been re-elected as prime minister.

– Bob Woodward has finally revealed the identity of Deep Throat, the man who unmasked him as journalist Carl Bernstein's partner in crime in the Washington Post in the 1970s. In an interview with the Los Angeles Times, Woodward reveals that he first learned the identity of the man who played a key role in exposing Bernstein's role in the Watergate scandal.

– A British soldier has been charged with the murder of an Iraqi man who tried to run over him with his car, the Telegraph reports. Lance Corporal Barry Singleton allegedly fired 12 times at the vehicle, hitting the man twice in the head and once in the chest. A military hearing will consider evidence against Singleton on Friday, following an investigation into claims that he fired his gun 12 times at a driver who tried to speed through a checkpoint.

– A 14-year-old Pakistani girl is in critical condition after being struck by a land mine as she walked on a road near her family's home, police say. The girl, identified as Sajeena Khan, was walking on the side of the road with her family when the bomb went off, injuring her foot and knocking her to the ground, reports the Telegraph.

– The semi-official IRNA news agency has declared moderate cleric Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani the winner of today's presidential election in Iran, reports the Telegraph. Rafsanjani is an ally of the supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei.

– Britain's ex-ambassador to Iraq has revealed that he turned down the job because he didn't believe the government's claim that Saddam Hussein had weapons of mass destruction. "I'd read the intelligence on WMD for four and a half years, and there's no way that it could sustain the case that the government was presenting," Carne Ross tells the Daily Mail.

– In the wake of the Boston Marathon bombing, many people were quick to point out the similarities between the attacks and the Boston Marathon bombings in Tamerlan and Dzhokhar Tsarnaev. “People were saying, ‘What about the Boston Marathon?’” one historian tells the Telegraph. “People were saying, ‘What about the Boston Marathon?’”

– Iraq's prime minister has rejected Donald Rumsfeld's claim that the US military has contacted some of the country's top insurgent leaders. Nouri al-Maliki said today that the military had not contacted him, the Telegraph reports.
– Democrats are furious over President Bush’s speech last night, in which he linked the Iraq war to the Sept. 11 attacks. “exploiting the sacred ground,” said Harry Reid.

– Coca-Cola has returned to Iraq after an absence of nearly four decades, triggering a cola war in a lucrative but potentially hostile market. Coca-Cola has returned to Iraq after an absence of nearly four decades, triggering a cola war in a lucrative but potentially hostile market

– British Prime Minister David Cameron is calling for an emergency meeting of world leaders to discuss the London bombings—and to discuss ways of preventing similar attacks in the future, the Telegraph reports. "We must do everything in our power to prevent such attacks happening again," he said. "We must do everything in our power to make sure that those responsible are brought to justice and we must do everything in our power to prevent attacks happening again."
– Karl Rove has told a grand jury that he discussed with journalists the identity of an outed CIA operative whose public identification has caused a political storm, US media reported today.

– A new poll has found that most Brits think the Iraq war and the London bombings had something to do with each other—and that the country is "riding as a pillion passenger with the United States in the war against terror," the Guardian reports.

– Three British soldiers will be charged with crimes against detainees in Iraq under the jurisdiction of the International Criminal Court, the attorney general announced today. It’s “a crushing blow for an army known and respected worldwide for its peacekeeping prowess and discipline,” the Telegraph reports.

– Jane Fonda has become the latest celebrity to speak out against the Iraq war. The 74-year-old actress, who visited North Vietnam as an anti-war activist in the 1970s, tells the Hollywood Reporter that she is "appalled" by the conduct of US troops in Iraq and that she hopes President Obama will do more to help veterans.

– The man accused of plotting to blow up London's subway system last year wasn't wearing a heavy jacket when he was shot dead by police, his cousin says. Jean Charles de Menezes wasn't wearing a heavy jacket that might have concealed a bomb, the cousin tells the Telegraph.

– One of the suspects in last week's failed terrorist attacks in London has claimed that the plot was inspired by Britain's involvement in the Iraq war, the Telegraph reports. Hussain Osman, arrested in Rome on Friday, says the men watched hours of TV footage showing Iraqi widows and children killed in the conflict alongside images of civilians killed in the conflict.

– One of the suicide bombers in the London bombings was actually a double agent working for the CIA, according to an Oxford University study. Ayman al-Qaeda's second-in-command Ayman al-Zawahri claimed responsibility for the attacks in a video released by al-Qaeda. One of the bombers was actually a double agent working for the CIA, according to the study.

– A former British foreign secretary has died after collapsing while walking in the Scottish hills. Robin Cook, 59, was airlifted to the hospital after falling ill while walking with his wife near the summit of Ben Stack, reports the Telegraph. Cook served as foreign secretary from 1997 to 2003.

– Thousands of protesters took to the streets of Baghdad and other Iraqi cities today to call for greater autonomy for the country's Shiite majority—and for an end to US military operations—in what is shaping up to be the biggest anti-US demonstration in years, the Telegraph reports.

– Nouri al-Maliki will be sworn in as Iraq’s new prime minister next week, CNN reports. Maliki will take over for Nouri al-Maliki, who was appointed by Shiite Grand Ayatollah Ali al-Sistani. Nouri al-Maliki will take over for Ayad Allawi, who was appointed by Shiite Grand Ayatollah Ali al-Sistani. Nouri al-Maliki will take over for Ayad Allawi, who was appointed by Shiite Grand Ayatollah Ali al-Sistani. Nouri al-Maliki will take over for Ayad Allawi, who was appointed by Shiite Grand Ayatollah Ali al-Sistani.
