Nouri al-Maliki will take over for Ayad Allawi, who was appointed by Shiite Grand Ayatollah Ali al-Sistani.

– A British MP has introduced a bill in the House of Commons that would make it legal for the country to declare war on another country—even if that country happens to be one of its own. Clare Short’s bill would bring Britain’s entry into the first world war into line with the modern world, the Guardian reports.

– Pat Robertson's call for the assassination of Fidel Castro's friend and fellow Venezuelan President Hugo Chavez is just the latest in a long line of anti-American rhetoric from the Christian televangelist, the Telegraph reports. "When the US and Britain begin to pull out troops from Iraq next year, as they hope, George Bush will do everything he can to ensure his three-year Iraq adventure is not portrayed as a total failure," writes Simon Schama.

– Britain's top official warned Prime Minister David Cameron that the Iraq war was "fueling Muslim extremism" in the country a year before the July 7 bombings, according to an leaked letter obtained by the Observer.

– The man accused of plotting to blow up New York City landmarks with explosives hidden inside his underwear has been charged with plotting to kill President Obama, CNN reports. Authorities say 25-year-old Diangelo Diggs Jr. told investigators that he had explosives hidden in his rectum and around his genitals, and that he planned to use them to blow up the White House, the Wall Street Journal reports.
– As New Orleans begins to dig out from the devastation of Hurricane Katrina, the Wall Street Journal takes a look at what went wrong in the city before the storm—and what’s happening now.

– As Reuters' Baghdad bureau chief after the fall of Saddam Hussein, Michael Brown faced one of the biggest safety risks of any US official—so he turned down the job, the Telegraph reports. "If I knew how dangerous it would be, I might have reconsidered taking the job," he said at the time.

– Christopher Hitchens and George Galloway squared off last night in a lively debate on Iraq, with Hitchens describing the British MP as a "disgrace" and Galloway as a "trail of slime," reports the Telegraph.

– News that Tony Blair told Rupert Murdoch the BBC's coverage of Hurricane Katrina was "full of hatred of America" and "gloating at the country's plight" has set off a minor uproar in Britain, the Telegraph reports.
– Armed dolphins trained by the US military to shoot terrorists and pinpoint spies underwater may be missing in the Gulf of Mexico after Hurricane Katrina, the Observer reports.

– The Conservative Party's annual conference—Britain's version of the Republican National Convention—is under way in Manchester, and the Telegraph takes a look at some of the buzzy things being said and written about it.

– The CIA planned to use a UN weapons inspection to remove Saddam Hussein from office—and it ended up killing him, an ex-Marine tells Nowthatsfuckedup.com. "This is big," says author Scott Ritter. "This is the most horror—filled website I have ever seen—and if you are reading this at breakfast or anywhere near a child, you should stop right now."

– A small amount of rabbit fever was detected on Washington DC's national mall during recent Iraq war protests, the Center for Disease Control and Prevention said today. The non- contagious disease, which causes sudden fever, chills, muscle aches, and pneumonia, is easily treated with antibiotics.

– Iraq war veteran M Scott Peck—who wrote the best-selling 1978 memoir The Road Less Travelled—has died at the age of 69, reports the Telegraph. He was diagnosed with schizoaffective personality disorder in the early 1980s and reportedly suffered from depression and anxiety for the rest of his life.

– France's interior minister has warned that the Paris attacks could be the work of al-Qaeda or an allied militant group, the Telegraph reports. Bernard Cazeneuve told lawmakers that investigators are looking into possible links between an Islamist militant group in Algeria and the killers of 130 people in the Bataclan concert hall.

– General Janis Karpinski was commander of Abu Ghraib prison when the abuse scandal erupted. In her memoir out this week she reveals her fury at being made the scapegoat I rarely fell asleep in Baghdad

– Zimbabwe's president has compared Tony Blair and George Bush to "international terrorists" and Benito Mussolini, the Telegraph reports. At a United Nations event to mark the 60th anniversary of the Food and Agriculture Organization, Robert Mugabe compared the British prime minister and the US president to the Nazi dictator.
– Gunmen abducted Guardian journalist Rory Carroll in Baghdad last night, CNN reports. Carroll, 33, was working on an interview with a victim of Saddam Hussein's regime when he was seized.

– British MP George Galloway has angrily rejected allegations that he lied under oath about the Saddam Hussein food program. The inquiry, headed by Republican Norm Coleman, claimed that Galloway knowingly made false or misleading statements under oath when he appeared before a committee hearing in Washington in May, the Telegraph reports.

– Relatives of some of those who died in the July 7 bombings are expected to boycott today's multi-faith service of remembrance at St Paul's Cathedral. Families of a handful of the 52 men and women who died are understood to be planning to stay away because they feel overwhelmed by anger

– Scooter Libby pleaded not guilty yesterday to five counts, including lying to a grand jury and obstruction of justice, in the CIA leak case. Libby is expected to testify against fellow top official Dick Cheney, the Telegraph reports.

– This week marks the first anniversary of the US-led invasion of Iraq, and the Los Angeles Times takes a look back at some of the ugliest battles of the conflict. One year ago today, US forces launched an assault on the Iraqi city of Falluja. “The destruction of Falluja was an act of barbarism that ranks alongside My Lai, Guernica and Halabja,” writes Richard Corliss.

– Peter Hitchens doesn’t like being called “bonkers Britain,” he tells the Mail on Sunday. “We live in a land of burglaries, muggings, swearing, pools of vomit, rave parties and traveller encampments,” he writes. “We live in a land of molten Old Testament fury shot through with visceral wit—we live in a land of burglaries, muggings, swearing, pools of vomit, MRSA, rave parties and traveller encampments.”

– The Obama administration has concluded that the use of chemical weapons by US troops in Iraq was a war crime, the New York Times reports. A Pentagon review found that the use of mustard gas and other chemical and biological agents, as well as chlorine gas, violated both the Geneva Convention and the International Criminal Court's rules on the use of force.

– A former top Colin Powell aide thinks Dick Cheney may have committed a war crime with his support of torture. Lawrence Wilkerson, who served as Powell’s chief of staff from 2002 to 2005, told the BBC that the vice president could be guilty of a war crime over the abuse of prisoners at Abu Ghraib.

– An Israeli newspaper reported yesterday that dozens of former members of Israel’s elite and covert forces were training Kurdish fighters in anti-terrorism techniques—and that Israeli firms were carrying out military training and commercial activities in Kurdish areas of north Iraq, according to reports in the Israeli newspaper Yedioth Ahronoth. Yedioth reported yesterday that dozens of former members of Israel’s elite and covert forces were training Kurdish fighters in anti-terrorism techniques John Gray, academic and writer and public intellectual, was an unlikely Thatcherite, then an early Blairite. He is now the scourge of neocons and the disciples of science and rationalism.
– At least 41 people were killed and 73 injured when two suicide bombers blew themselves up in a police academy classroom in east Baghdad Wednesday, the Telegraph reports.

– Casey Sheehan, the anti-war activist whose son died in Iraq, has been arrested for protesting outside George W. Bush’s ranch in Texas, the Telegraph reports. “I feel I’m carrying the world on my shoulders,” she said yesterday on ITV’s This Morning.

– George Bush has finally acknowledged that much of the intelligence leading up to the invasion of Iraq was wrong—but he's still standing by the decision to go to war, the Telegraph reports. "Mr. Bush has acknowledged flaws in US intelligence on Iraq before, but this was his most wholehearted acknowledgment to date of the scale of the errors underlying his administration's allegations over Saddam Hussein's alleged weapons of mass destruction."

– James Meek of the Los Angeles Times takes a look back at some of the best war films of all time—the Deer Hunter, Jarhead, and even Citizen Kane—and sums up the genre as "a genre whose explosions keep going off in newspaper columns and political discourse long after the closing credits have rolled."

– President Obama is calling for an end to US drone strikes in the Mideast, saying the strikes are necessary to defeat al-Qaeda and other militant groups bent on destabilizing the region, the Washington Post reports. "We must stop the flow of weapons into the Mideast and we must stop the flow of people and money into the region," the president said in an interview with CNN. "We must stop the flow of money into the region and we must stop the flow of people and weapons into the region."

– A battle between Iraqi security forces and inmates at a high-security prison has left nine people dead, including two guards, in Baghdad, CNN reports. Officials say the inmates were trying to escape when guards opened fire.

– The wave of pro-democracy protests sweeping the Middle East and North Africa have turned violent: Libyan police fired on protesters in the coastal city of Benghazi today, and at least two people were killed, CNN reports. In Yemen, thousands of protesters gathered in the capital of Sanaa to call for the ouster of President Ali Abdullah Saleh, and in Bahrain, protesters have camped out at a landmark for a second day. In Iran, thousands turned out for a funeral of a man claimed by both sides.

– Libyan security forces opened fire on protesters today, in what appeared to be the worst violence yet in a week of demonstrations against leader Moammar Gadhafi. At least 20 people were reportedly killed today, according to a doctor at a hospital in Benghazi, CNN reports. The US condemned the violence, with Secretary of State Hillary Clinton calling it “deeply disturbing” and urging the Libyan government to allow peaceful protests to take place.

– Hillary Clinton condemned the “unacceptable bloodshed” being unleashed on protesters in Libya today, and called for a halt to the violence, CNN reports. “The government of Libya has a responsibility to respect the universal rights of the people, including the right to free expression and assembly,” Clinton said. “Like you and many others around the world, I have seen very disturbing and shocking scenes, where Libyan authorities have been firing at demonstrators from warplanes and helicopters.”

– The UN Security Council has unanimously approved sanctions against Moammar Gadhafi's government for its violent crackdown on protesters, CNN reports. The sanctions include an arms embargo, an asset freeze, and a travel ban. Meanwhile, al-Qaeda's North African wing, al-Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb, said in a statement that it will do whatever it can to help the uprising.

– Moammar Gadhafi is blaming al-Qaeda for the current unrest in Libya, he tells ABC and the BBC in an interview airing today. “Al-Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb, al-Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb, they are trying to create chaos in the country,” he says. “No demonstration at all in the streets. They love me, all my people with me.” Gadhafi also denied that protesters were calling for his exit, CNN reports.

– Moammar Gadhafi has lost control of the oil port of Ras Lanuf, CNN reports, as well as other key cities in the western part of the country. The news comes as Gadhafi’s forces continue their assault on Zawiya, and as the UN Security Council prepares to meet on the situation.

– Opposition forces claimed a major victory today in Libya, managing to block an onslaught by Moammar Gadhafi's troops and maintain control of the key city of Misrata, an eyewitness tells CNN. Using machine guns, sticks, and anything else they could find, crowds protected the courthouse, serving as an operations center by the opposition in Misrata, and successfully repelled Gadhafi militias armed with tanks and heavy artillery. The UN's chief talks today with Libya's foreign minister, urging end to violence. A doctor says at least 42 were killed in Misrata; the UN says aid has been blocked Libyan state TV says troops are under orders not to enter cities controlled by gangs.

– Moammar Gadhafi’s forces bombed the oil port of Ras Lanuf today as part of their assault on the rebel-held city of Ras Lanuf, witnesses tell CNN. The town has been under rebel control since last week.

– The Arab League has voted in favor of a no-fly zone over Libya, and called on the UN to do the same, reports CNN. But Moammar Gadhafi's regime, meanwhile, is stepping up its attacks on rebels, notes the New York Times, with tanks rolling into the city of Zawiya.

– The US has joined the coalition targeting Moammar Gadhafi's air defenses in Libya, CNN reports. Earlier, the US fired at least 20 Tomahawk missiles at 20 radar and communication sites in the western part of the country. The coalition, which includes the US, Britain, and France, is trying to impose a no-fly zone to stop Gadhafi's forces from attacking civilians.

– The New York Times has confirmed that four of its journalists are missing in Libya, and says Moammar Gadhafi's government has promised to release them. The missing are Lynsey Addario, a female photographer; Anthony Shadid, a Pulitzer Prize-winning journalist; and Serge Kovaleski and Bill Keller, who were covering the conflict in the country for the Times. Gadhafi's government says it has no information on the four, CNN reports.

– New York Gov. Andrew Cuomo has declared a state of emergency in several counties in the New York tri-state area, in what is believed to be a first in the state. Gov. Andrew Cuomo has declared a state of emergency in 23 counties in the New York tri-state region, which includes New York state. New York Gov. Andrew Cuomo has declared a state of emergency in 21 counties in the New York tri-state region, which includes New York state.

– President Obama has a message for Moammar Gadhafi: "We will be victorious," he tells CNN in an interview that airs tonight. "My message to him is: You're not going to succeed. You're not going to get re-elected. You're not going to get power. You're not going to get control of Tripoli. You're not going to get control of Benghazi. You're not going to get control of Tripoli. You're not going to get control of western Libya." The interview comes as coalition forces continue to pound Gadhafi's forces from the air.

– Moammar Gadhafi's forces have pulled back from the strategic oil port of Ras Lanuf, leaving the city in rebel hands, opposition officials tell CNN. Ras Lanuf had been seen as a potential prize for the opposition, but it was captured by Gadhafi's forces earlier this month. The loss of the city has put the brakes on the opposition's advance west toward Tripoli.

– A Libyan woman who claims she was raped by Moammar Gadhafi's forces has been released after two days in captivity, CNN reports. Eman al-Obeidy burst into a hotel Saturday, telling foreign reporters she had been raped for two days by Gadhafi's troops. A government spokesman says Obeidy is at home with her family and the matter is being investigated. Obeidy's family says they were offered money to convince her to change her story.

– Moammar Gadhafi's foreign minister has defected, CNN reports, making him the highest-ranking Libyan official to leave the regime so far. Moussa Koussa, Libya's former intelligence chief and foreign minister, arrived at an airport outside London on a commercial plane, raising hopes that the defection will lead to greater international pressure on Gadhafi. But it's not all good news for the rebels: They've lost the oil port of Ras Lanuf to Gadhafi's forces, and they've been pushed back to the outskirts of Misrata, their only major stronghold in the western part of the country.

– Moammar Gadhafi’s forces continued their assault on the oil port of Brega today, with tanks moving in from the east and artillery from the west, according to an opposition spokesman. “They have surrounded the town,” the spokesman told CNN. “They are firing rockets at us from various places, and they are shelling us from the air.” At least 20 people have been killed in today’s fighting in Brega, according to the Telegraph.

– The Libyan woman who says she was gang-raped by Moammar Gadhafi's forces wants humanitarian organizations to come to Tripoli to see for themselves, CNN reports. Eman al-Obeidy says she's not intimidated by Gadhafi's presence in Tripoli, calling him a "humble man." Obeidy says she wants to clear her name, and wants to meet with Gadhafi.

– The African Union says Moammar Gadhafi has agreed in principal to a deal to end the conflict in Libya, CNN reports. African Union President Jacob Zuma says the deal will include a cease-fire between Gadhafi's forces and rebels, an end to airstrikes, and a transition to a democratic government. The African Union will hold talks with rebel leaders tomorrow.

– Forces loyal to Moammar Gadhafi have fired cluster munitions into residential areas in the besieged western city of Misrata, Human Rights Watch said today. The group accused Gadhafi’s forces of using the weapons against civilians, CNN reports.

– Moammar Gadhafi’s forces continued their shelling of Misrata today, as the European Union said it was considering sending troops to help the rebels, CNN reports. The EU “is prepared to send troops for humanitarian assistance if requested” by the UN, according to a statement from Britain.

– A NATO airstrike hit a building in Tripoli today that was being used as a command and control center for Moammar Gadhafi’s forces, killing three people, a spokesman for the Libyan government tells CNN. The strike hit a parking lot outside Gadhafi’s Bab el-Aziziya compound, but it’s not clear whether the building was actually hit, CNN notes.

– Loyalists to Libyan leader Moammar Gadhafi killed eight rebel fighters in a rare attack earlier this week in an opposition held region near the Egyptian border, a medical official and an opposition spokesman told CNN today. The rebels were guarding an oil pumping station in the Libyan desert Thursday, about 186 miles southwest of Tobruk, said Dr. CNN Student News. The regime loyalists, riding in a convoy of nine vehicles, attacked the oil pumping station in the Libyan desert on Thursday, about 300 kilometers, 186 miles southwest of Tobruk, said Dr. CNN Student News.

– The Libyan government has vowed to sink any ship that approaches the besieged port city of Misrata, effectively threatening NATO patrols and humanitarian aid ships that have been bringing in food and medical supplies and ferrying out refugees, CNN reports. The threat came hours after NATO said it intercepted Libyan government forces laying mines in Misrata's harbor, which has been a lifeline for humanitarian aid in the months—long conflict between troops loyal to Moammar Gadhafi and rebels demanding an end to the dictator's four-decade rule.

– The Libyan government says Moammar Gadhafi's son and three of his grandchildren were killed in a NATO airstrike yesterday, and that the strongman and his wife are alive and well, CNN reports. The strike killed one of Gadhafi's sons, Saadi, and three of his grandchildren, according to the Libyan government. The government says it regrets the attacks on foreign embassies that occurred after the strike, and that it will make Libya the grave of NATO invaders.

– The UN has issued arrest warrants for Moammar Gadhafi, his son Saif al-Islam, and other Libyan officials for war crimes, CNN reports. The warrants were issued by the Security Council after a closed-door meeting today, according to a diplomat who was present. The diplomat says the charges will be presented to the Security Council tomorrow.

– The UN's human rights chief today accused Moammar Gadhafi of crimes against humanity in the assault on Misrata, CNN reports. Gadhafi's forces have killed and wounded scores of civilians in the city over the last few days, says Zeid Ra'ad al-Hussein. Gadhafi's forces have also fired rockets and mortars at Benghazi, the capital of Libya's eastern region, and there have been reports of Scud missiles being fired at Tripoli, notes the New York Times.

– Four rockets hit Moammar Gadhafi’s compound in Tripoli this morning, and a Libyan government official tells CNN that at least two emergency vehicles were speeding toward the compound after the blasts.

– A boat carrying at least 166 migrants from Libya arrived at the Italian island of Lampedusa today, in what is believed to be the latest example of Europe's failure to deal with a huge influx of migrants, CNN reports. The migrants, many of whom are from sub-Saharan Africa, are believed to be the first to arrive at the tiny island in recent weeks.

– The chief prosecutor of the International Criminal Court says Libyan security forces are using Viagra and machetes to rape women stopped at checkpoints, CNN reports. Luis Moreno says the rapes are organized and the issue is who organized them. " Viagra is a tool of massive rape," says Moreno, who didn't say how many women have been raped since the conflict began.

– Forces loyal to Moammar Gadhafi have launched their biggest attack yet against a rebel stronghold in the mountains of western Libya, one of the Libyan leader's former generals tells CNN. Over the past two days, Gadhafi's forces have unleashed their biggest attack yet against one of the mountainous rebel strongholds in western Libya, according to one of his former generals.

– NATO has hit Moammar Gadhafi's compound with more than a dozen airstrikes in Tripoli, in what is believed to be one of the heaviest attacks on the capital since the campaign began. A NATO official tells CNN that the strikes hit a building near Gadhafi's Bab al-Aziziya compound that was used by Gadhafi's inner circle as a command and control center. NATO also hit a number of Gadhafi loyalists near Tajura, about 20 miles east of Tripoli.

– The head of Libya's opposition government has welcomed a call for Moammar Gadhafi to step down from Russian President Dmitry Medvedev, CNN reports. "I believe we are in the frontline but with a voice, not with a gun," says rebel leader Abdel Hafez Ghoga. The head of Libya's opposition government told reporters today he welcomed a call Friday by Russian President Dmitry Medvedev for Gadhafi to step down.

– Moammar Gadhafi has agreed to a cease-fire with rebel forces, according to South African President Jacob Zuma, who met with the Libyan leader today. "We have reached an agreement with Gadhafi that he will accept the African Union's proposal for a cease-fire," Zuma told reporters, according to CNN. Gadhafi has also agreed to NATO's plan to step down by the end of the month, according to the president.

– NATO has used attack helicopters for the first time as part of its military operation aimed at increasing pressure on Libyan leader Moammar Gadhafi's regime, CNN reports. The move came as NATO Secretary-General Anders Fogh Rasmussen said that the coalition was "closer than ever" to striking Gadhafi's forces.

– As NATO continues to pound Moammar Gadhafi's forces in Libya, Human Rights Watch says the rebels there are arbitrarily detaining people suspected of being loyal to the leader. At least one person is believed to have died while in the custody of the rebels, CNN reports. The report comes as Russian President Dmitry Medvedev sent an envoy to Libya to meet with rebels trying to bring about an end to Gadhafi's 42-year rule, a move that comes after he called for the Libyan leader to step down. Mikhail Margelov, the presidential special envoy on Africa, was expected to meet with leaders of the rebel Transitional National Council based in Benghazi.

– Forces loyal to Moammar Gadhafi launched a major attack on the rebel-held city of Misrata today, with heavy shelling from three sides, rebels tell CNN. At least 13 people have been killed and 60 wounded in the fighting, according to the rebels. Gadhafi's forces have also launched an attack on the oil port of Ras Lanuf.

– South Africa's president has a message for NATO: Don't mess with Moammar Gadhafi. President Jacob Zuma says the alliance's current focus on enforcing the no-fly zone over Libya is "irresponsible," CNN reports. "We don't want to create a situation in which Gadhafi has more power than the Libyan people," he says. "That is something we cannot afford." Zuma's comments come after NATO rejected a rebel claim that Gadhafi has been hiding rockets in the UNESCO World Heritage site of Leptis Magna. NATO can't verify the claim, however.

– Libyan rebels say they've found videos on captured Gadhafi soldiers showing the regime's henchmen raping women and torturing people, CNN reports. The videos are so graphic that one rebel commander has erased evidence of the rapes from cell phones seized from captured soldiers, according to the network. The Libyan government, however, denies the allegations.

– A NATO airstrike on a residential building west of Tripoli early today killed at least 15 people, including three children, according to the Libyan government. NATO, which could not confirm the casualties, issued a statement saying it had hit a "legitimate military target," CNN reports. "We would regret any loss of civilian life and we go to great lengths to avoid civilian casualties," the alliance said.

– Seventeen members of Libya’s national soccer team have defected to the rebels, opposition spokesmen tell CNN, in the latest blow to Moammar Gadhafi. The defecting players were greeted by cheering crowds and celebratory gunfire in the rebel town of Zintan. The defections are another setback for Libyan leader Moammar Gadhafi.

– The International Criminal Court has issued arrest warrants for Moammar Gadhafi and two of his sons on charges of crimes against humanity, reports CNN. The ICC says it has evidence of rapes during the conflict, but can't prove that Gadhafi himself ordered them.

– As NATO steps up its bombing of Moammar Gadhafi's regime, more women are joining the fight, CNN reports. Women from Tripoli and around Gadhafi's stronghold of Tripoli have been traveling south to a training facility in Bani Walid to practice with weapons, a common sight in a country where young girls receive military training in schools.

– If Moammar Gadhafi steps down, he can stay in Libya as long as he remains under supervision, rebel leader Abdel Hafez Ghoga told state-run TV today. “If he resigns, we don’t have a problem with him staying in Libya,” Ghoga said, according to CNN. “As long as he remains under supervision, we don’t have a problem with him staying in Libya.”

– Libyan leader Moammar Gadhafi's son was killed in a NATO airstrike near the capital of Tripoli on Sunday, reports Reuters. Col. Saadi Gadhafi was killed along with three other members of his security forces in the town of Jedaim, NATO said in a statement. The strikes were in response to reports that Gadhafi's forces were gathering near the town of Jedaim to launch attacks on NATO bases in the country. NATO said it was investigating the reports.

– Rebels say they’ve ousted Moammar Gadhafi’s forces from the western Libyan village of Qawalish, CNN reports. The fighters appear spirited, flashing victory signs, and posing for photos—aided by NATO strikes—as they’re hoping to unseat the longtime Libyan leader. Almost all civilians have fled the western Libya area around Qawalish, hoping to avoid the worst of the violence wracking the nation. Yet there is a buzz around this village, which is in the hands of rebel fighters eager to defeat forces loyal to longtime Libyan leader Gadhafi.

– Moammar Gadhafi's forces are closing in on the oil port of Brega, and a government spokesman says they'll turn the city into "hell" rather than let it fall to the rebels, CNN reports. "We will turn Brega into hell," the spokesman said. "Instead of letting it fall into the hands of advancing rebel forces, we are going to fight to the end." Rebels, however, say they're closing in on Gadhafi's troops about 12 miles from Brega.

– Moammar Gadhafi's forces have launched a major assault on the oil port of Brega, and a government spokesman told reporters last night that the attack was "heavy, merciless, and surprising," CNN reports. "It is impossible for me to leave my loyal people," he said. "We will win over the campaign of colonization, the campaign of hatred."

– The conflict in Libya has cost the country some $50 billion since it began five months ago, according to the Libyan government. “The cost is colossal,” the country’s planning and finance minister tells CNN. The country’s oil and gas exports have been cut off, and construction projects that were abandoned as a result of the conflict are still visible around the country.

– Germany has agreed to lend 144 million euros to Libyan rebels, even though it stayed out of NATO's bombing campaign against Moammar Gadhafi's forces, CNN reports. The money will be repaid from unfrozen assets Germany previously announced a smaller loan of 10 million euros.

– Britain has kicked Moammar Gadhafi’s diplomats out of London, a move that has cinched the Libyan regime’s grip on power, writes Ivan Watson and Jomana Karadsheh for CNN. “Barely 15 days ago, there was optimism from regime insiders here in Tripoli that a deal was in the works to resolve the five-month conflict,” writes Watson. But now, “the bloody test of wills in Libya will grind on for weeks, if not months to come.”

– The body of Libyan rebel military chief Abdel Fattah Younes, who was killed yesterday along with two of his aides, has been found in a car in Benghazi, CNN reports. Younes was recalled from the front line for questioning by the International Criminal Court yesterday, and rebel leader Mustafa Abdul-Jalil says they were killed by gunmen after being recalled from the front for questioning by judges. A spokesman for Moammar Gadhafi says the killing shows "that those forces are in disarray."

– Moammar Gadhafi's son has resigned from his post as head of Libya's National Security Council, CNN reports. Saif al-Islam Gadhafi, who had been leading an investigation into the US-led bombing of Moammar Gadhafi's forces, has resigned from the post "effective immediately," according to a statement from his office. Saif al-Islam Gadhafi had been leading an investigation into the US-led bombing of Moammar Gadhafi's forces, CNN reports.

– Moammar Gadhafi's forces fired a missile at an Italian warship in the Mediterranean Sea today, in a rare attack on NATO, CNN reports. The missile hit the Bersagliere, one of the NATO vessels near Libya's coast. "We have n't used our real military power," a Gadhafi spokesman said.

– The Libyan government says it has retaken the western town of Bir al-Ghanam after losing it to rebel forces yesterday, CNN reports. But a rebel commander says the opposition still has control of the town, 53 miles from Tripoli, with little between.

– Rebels say they're closing in on Moammar Gadhafi's Tripoli compound and expect to be in the capital within days, CNN reports. The opposition National Transitional Council says it's now in control of most of the western part of the country, including the oil port of Ras Lanuf and the town of Jedaim. "Within a few days we will be in Tripoli," a rebel spokesman says. "If Gadhafi doesn't leave, we will be in Tripoli."
– Libyan strongman Moammar Gadhafi has fled the country for neighboring Tunisia, CNN reports. A CNN photographer was with him when he got the news, and was forced to return to Libya.

– NATO says Moammar Gadhafi's forces have made "significant advances" in the last few days, taking control of Misrata and Brega and waiting for NATO's "no-fly zone" to end, CNN reports. But in Zawiya, Gadhafi's last major stronghold, rebel forces are fighting an urban warfare battle that a NATO spokesman calls "the zero hour."

– Rebel fighters are battling Moammar Gadhafi's forces for the western Libyan city of Zawiya, Reuters reports. The rebels are trying to take over the city, which is about 30 miles west of Tripoli, in an effort to advance on Tripoli in their fight to oust Gadhafi, who has controlled the country for decades.

– A top Libyan official says Moammar Gadhafi, his family, and his security team are still in Tripoli, despite reports that they've fled the country. But a rebel official tells CNN that a " coordinated Tripoli operation" is under way to oust Gadhafi, and that the leader, his wife, and children aren't leaving yet.

– Moammar Gadhafi’s security forces opened fire on protesters in the capital of Tripoli today, witnesses tell Reuters, in the first serious violence in the city. “They are shooting in the air and they are using live ammunition,” said one witness. “They are firing into the air and they are using Kalashnikovs.” In the east of the country, security forces have bombed protesters in the city of Benghazi, the Guardian reports. The unrest has spread to the capital, with residents reporting gunfire in parts of Tripoli, and one political activist said warplanes had bombed the city. Meanwhile, Gadhafi’s son, Saif al-Islam, promised reforms in an address on state TV yesterday, but hit out at the protesters behind the unrest, which has killed more than 200 over the past few days, according to human rights groups.

– Libyans celebrating the liberation of the east of the country from the rule of Moammar Gadhafi, who has vowed to crush the revolt, were met with gunfire from security forces in the west of the country. Gadhafi, meanwhile, was trying to assert his grip on the capital Tripoli, in the west. Lying between Egypt and Tunisia, where a wave of Arab unrest has unseated two veteran presidents, the desert nation of six million which Gadhafi has ruled for 41 years seemed split in two, trapping thousands of foreign workers and jeopardizing oil exports and raising fears of tribal conflict and civil war, reports the New York Times.

– With Moammar Gadhafi clinging to power and rebels closing in on the capital, the US and its European allies are considering a wide range of military options to stop the Libyan leader. “What the Libyan nation is going through has opened the door to all options, and now the signs of civil war and foreign interference have started,” Gadhafi’s son, Saif al-Islam, told Al Arabiya, according to Reuters.

– Libyan strongman Moammar Gadhafi says he will not step down, even as the US and its European allies consider military options including a no-fly zone. “We will not leave Gadhafi,” the Libyan leader said in a televised speech today, according to the BBC. “We will not leave, we will not leave, we will not give up, we will not give up.” He said he would dedicate his remaining time to defending his country against “the crusaders,” and warned that the Libyan people would “pay the price” if the US and its allies intervene. Hillary Clinton, meanwhile, said the US was considering a “no-fly zone” over Libya to prevent Gadhafi from attacking civilian areas.

– Moammar Gadhafi blamed al-Qaeda and other “terrorists” for the unrest currently engulfing Libya, but said he would not step down. “There is a conspiracy to control Libyan oil and to control Libyan land, to colonize Libya once again,” he said in a speech on state television. “This is impossible, impossible.” He said no more than 150 people had been killed in the unrest, according to Reuters, which has the full speech.

– One of Moammar Gadhafi’s sons said today that Libya would descend into civil war if his father steps down. “My father hasn’t even thrown his army yet,” Saadi Gadhafi said in an interview with Al Arabiya, according to Reuters. “We will enter a civil war if he doesn’t leave.” Saadi Gadhafi also said Libya would become a new Somalia, and that the country’s tribes would fight against each other. Two Arab newspapers reported today that Gadhafi was looking for an agreement allowing him to step down, but there was no official confirmation.

– France has officially recognized the Libyan National Council as the country’s legitimate government, the first country to do so. “We recognize the Libyan National Council as the legitimate representative of the people of Libya,” said Nicolas Sarkozy. He called it “the only legitimate representative of the people of Libya.” The recognition comes as Moammar Gadhafi’s forces continue their assault on rebel strongholds, including Zawiyah, which the International Committee of the Red Cross says is “strategically significant” because it’s close to Gadhafi’s power base in Tripoli.

– Forces loyal to Moammar Gadhafi launched a major offensive against the rebel-held city of Misrata today, sending in tanks, artillery, and warplanes. But rebels said they had stalled the Gadhafi forces' ground assault on the city, the last major rebel stronghold in western Libya, and seized some of the pro-Gadhafi tanks, reports Reuters.

– The US says Moammar Gadhafi has defied the UN Security Council's demand for an immediate ceasefire in Libya. US Ambassador to the UN Susan Rice said in a statement that Gadhafi has ignored the "clear demands of the United Nations Security Council." She said the US has made it clear to Gadhafi that the US will not stand idly by if he doesn't stop the bombardment of his forces by the US and its allies.

– US forces launched another round of air strikes against Libya last night, this time targeting Moammar Gadhafi’s air defenses. The strikes were launched after Gadhafi’s forces continued their assault on the rebel-held city of Benghazi, and were aimed at making sure the dictator’s air defenses were not falling into the hands of opposition fighters. US officials said the strikes were aimed at making sure Gadhafi’s forces didn’t continue their assault on Benghazi, the Wall Street Journal reports. In other developments: France said it would ask the UN Security Council to impose a no-fly zone over the country, and authorize the use of force by the US if necessary, Reuters reports. British Prime Minister David Cameron said his country would not be dragged into another Iraq-style conflict.

– Libyan rebels say they have retaken the strategic town of Ajdabiyah from Moammar Gadhafi’s forces, reports the New York Times. The development comes as US forces continue to pound Gadhafi’s forces from the air. Ajdabiyah had been seen as a potential turning point for the rebels, who have been unable to make much headway against Gadhafi’s forces in the western part of the country.

– Forces loyal to Moammar Gadhafi have retaken the oil port of Ras Lanuf after a two-day battle with rebels, al-Jazeera reports. Ras Lanuf had been the rebels’ main holdout until yesterday, when NATO launched airstrikes to try to stop Gadhafi’s forces from using heavy artillery against rebel-held cities. NATO says it will continue to hit Gadhafi’s forces until they comply with the international call to step down.

– Forces loyal to Libyan leader Muammar Gaddafi are staging a massacre in the besieged city of Misrata, evacuees said yesterday, as Turkey said it was trying to broker a ceasefire to halt the bloodshed. A government spokesman said Libya was ready for a “political solution” with world powers. Western powers have destroyed nearly a third of Libyan leader Moammar Gadhafi’s military since launching air strikes last month, but NATO said it was forced to change bombing tactics because of human shields. The besieged city of Misrata, the only big population center in western Libya where a revolt against Gadhafi has not been crushed, is now the priority for NATO air strikes.

– The head of Libya’s rebel army slammed NATO for its slow response to air strikes against Moammar Gadhafi’s forces, saying the alliance was “letting the people of Misrata die every day.” The besieged city of Misrata, the only major population center in western Libya where a revolt against Gadhafi has not been crushed, is now the priority for NATO air strikes, alliance officials said earlier. Jordan has sent fighter aircraft to a European air base to support a no-fly zone over Libya and protect humanitarian flights from the Arab kingdom, Reuters reports.

– Moammar Gadhafi has agreed to a plan to end the conflict in Libya, according to South African President Jacob Zuma, who led a delegation of African leaders to Tripoli for talks. “He has accepted the roadmap,” Zuma said, according to the Telegraph. “We are confident that this roadmap will be approved by the Libyan government.” The African leaders are calling for NATO to stop air strikes on Libya, and for Gadhafi to step down.

– The African Union’s peace plan for Libya has fallen apart as Moammar Gadhafi’s forces continue their assault on the rebel-held city of Misrata. The AU’s top official in the country said Gadhafi had accepted the plan, but rebels quickly rejected it, saying there would be no deal until Gadhafi left power, Reuters reports. South African President Jacob Zuma said Gadhafi had accepted the plan, including a ceasefire, but rebels said the ceasefire was meaningless as Gadhafi’s forces continued their assault on Misrata.

– Rebels say they are closing in on Moammar Gadhafi's forces at the oil port of Brega, after taking control of the town of Ajdabiyah. “We are now in full control of Ajdabiyah,” their military leader said, according to the New York Times. “God willing, Brega will be liberated in a few days.” But Gadhafi’s forces remain in control of the other two major oil ports in the area, Ras Lanuf and Zawiyah, the Times notes.

– France says it will step up air strikes against Moammar Gadhafi’s forces and send military liaison officers to help anti-Gadhafi rebels in Misrata. The announcement comes as the UN warned that Gadhafi’s reported use of cluster munitions and heavy weapons in Misrata may amount to crimes under international law, Reuters reports.

– Moroccan officials have met with representatives of Moammar Gadhafi and rebels this week in an attempt to forge a political solution to the Libyan crisis, an official source tells Reuters. The source gave no details on how close any such deal might be or what it might entail. Meanwhile, the Guardian reports that Gadhafi's forces appear to be on the verge of defeat.

– The African Union today accused Western nations of undermining its efforts to find a solution to the Libya conflict, and said the civil war was in danger of becoming a stalemate. The AU said it was sending its foreign minister, Abdelati Obeidi, and two representatives of the rebels to discuss a possible solution with African Union officials. Earlier this month, rebels rejected a plan by the AU to halt the civil war in Libya because it did not include the departure of Moammar Gadhafi and his sons.

– Forces loyal to Moammar Gadhafi launched a major attack on the city of Misrata last night, setting off a furious gunfight with rebel fighters that left at least 10 dead, al-Jazeera reports. Misrata is Libya’s third-largest city and has been besieged by Gadhafi’s forces since the beginning of the conflict. Rebels say they have no choice but to accept NATO’s demands for an end to the bombardment, but Gadhafi’s forces continue to pound the city with bombs and rockets.

– Moammar Gadhafi survived a NATO airstrike that killed his youngest son and three grandchildren, a government spokesman said today. “What we have now is the law of the jungle,” he told reporters, according to Reuters. The strike killed Gadhafi’s youngest son Seif al-Islam, and his three grandchildren, said government spokesman Mussa Ibrahim.

– The International Criminal Court has issued an arrest warrant for Moammar Gadhafi over the killing of unarmed Libyans by security forces, reports the BBC. The warrant will allow the court to try the leader on charges of crimes against humanity for the killing of the protesters, as well as for the use of force against them. The move comes as Gadhafi’s forces continue their assault on the western city of Misrata.

– Moammar Gadhafi’s forces shelled the rebel-held city of Misrata today, killing at least six people and wounding more, according to a Sky News correspondent. Misrata has been cut off from the rest of the country as Gadhafi’s forces continue their assault on the city. The United Nations Security Council has authorized non-military aid for the rebels, but Russia today criticized the plan, warning that it must not seek to usurp the authority of the UN, Reuters reports.

– Al-Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb has received weapons from Moammar Gadhafi’s former regime in Libya, the New York Times reports. The weapons include SA-7 missiles looted from Gadhafi’s abandoned arms caches. “These weapons will allow al-Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb to plan and carry out attacks against the West,” said a spokesman for Libya’s National Transitional Council.

– The International Criminal Court has issued arrest warrants for Moammar Gadhafi, his son Saif al-Islam Gadhafi, and Libya’s spy chief on charges of crimes against humanity. ICC prosecutor Luis Moreno-Ocampo had earlier said he would seek three arrest warrants for Gadhafi, his son, and Libya’s spy chief over the killing of protesters.

– The European Union is considering blacklisting six Libyan ports as part of new sanctions against Moammar Gadhafi’s regime, a source tells Reuters. The ports would be banned from exporting oil and from importing fuel. EU experts are working on the sanctions list and proposals could be submitted to the EU sanctions committee next week.

– South African President Jacob Zuma plans to visit Libya next week to discuss an exit strategy for Moammar Gadhafi with the Libyan leader, Talk Radio 702 reported today. The visit is in the planning stages and will be aimed at discussing ways for Gadhafi to exit, the radio station said, citing sources in Tripoli. But the statement made no mention of the US.

– In Libya's civil war, there is "a conspicuous lack of the deep and fractious animosities that fuelled internal conflicts in Iraq, Northern Ireland, Rwanda, Libya's neighbor Algeria and elsewhere," writes Andrew Roth in the Guardian. "In Libya's rebel—held east—there is a conspicuous lack of the deep and fractious animosities that fuelled internal conflicts in Iraq, Northern Ireland, Rwanda, Libya's neighbor Algeria and elsewhere."

– China has made its first confirmed contact with Libyan rebels, Reuters reports, and France says it’s working with those close to Moammar Gadhafi to persuade him to leave power. Meanwhile, the Telegraph reports that Gadhafi’s wife has fled the country.

– The EU today added six Libyan ports to the list of those whose assets are frozen as a result of sanctions against Moammar Gadhafi, Reuters reports. “In view of the gravity of the situation in the country, the EU council adopted a decision today extending the assets freeze to six Libyan port authorities,” said a statement from the European Council, “in view of the gravity of the situation in the country.”

– Heavy fighting broke out between Moammar Gadhafi’s forces and rebels in the town of Zawiyah today, shutting down the coastal highway that links Tripoli to Tunisia. Gadhafi’s forces also shelled the first time the world heritage listed city of Gadamis, some 600 miles southwest of the capital on the Tunisia and Algerian border, opening a new front in the five-month long civil war, reports Reuters.

– Russia’s ambassador to NATO warned today that the alliance could be on the brink of a ground war with Libya. “NATO could be sliding into a ground war,” Dmitry Rogozin said, according to the Telegraph. “This is not a question of if, but when.” He said NATO was trying to kill Moammar Gadhafi, and that the conflict could cause “dire consequences” for Europe.

– Libya’s rebel oil chief says the country’s Transitional National Council has run out of cash after months of fighting and the West has failed to live up to its promises to deliver financial aid. “We are running out of money,” Abdul Fattah Younis tells Reuters. “We are running out of food. We are running out of money to pay the security forces. We are running out of money to pay the salaries of the fighters.” Younis said the West had promised to deliver $300 million in humanitarian aid, but so far the promises have not been kept.

– A NATO airstrike on the home of one of Moammar Gadhafi’s top officials killed 19 civilians, the Libyan government said today. The strike hit the home of Khouildi Hamidi, a member of Libya’s powerful Revolutionary Command Council, led by Gadhafi, the Telegraph reports. Libyan officials took reporters to the site of what they said was a NATO air strike on the home of Khouildi Hamidi.

– The oversupply of natural gas currently plaguing the world could end as early as winter 2012 thanks to the unrest in the Middle East and Japan’s earthquake, Reuters reports. The oversupply of gas, which was previously forecast to end in 2015, will now likely end in 2013 and possibly as early as 2012 as a combination of factors, including supply cuts due to Middle East turmoil and increasing demand from quake-hit Japan.

– The Department of Homeland Security has issued a warning to US citizens and visitors to the United States because of the ongoing unrest in the Mideast and North Africa, the Wall Street Journal reports. According to the department's website, the public is not advised to travel to places such as Libya, Somalia, Sudan, and Yemen.

– Moammar Gadhafi’s 42-year rule could end in a “new Somalia,” the World Bank’s representative in Libya tells Reuters. “If this civil war goes on, it would be a new Somalia, which I do n’t say lightly,” said Marouane Abassi, who has been in Tunisia since February. Gadhafi’s rule would be a “new Somalia,” because Libyans could end up “in the hands of extremists instead of the liberal economic technocrats who now lead its rebel movement,” he said. Meanwhile, NATO has stepped up its air strikes against Gadhafi’s forces, the Wall Street Journal reports.

– A delegation of Libyan tribal representatives arrived in Egypt today and said they would hold talks with rebel leaders to seek to end the country’s civil war. The delegation will meet with a number of Libyans in Egypt, especially the Benghazi opposition, to reach a solution to the Libyan crisis so stability and economic security returns,” said one of the 19 delegation members. Meanwhile, the Telegraph reports that Moammar Gadhafi’s whereabouts are unknown after a NATO airstrike in the western part of the country.

– Rebel fighters in western Libya faced sustained artillery and rocket bombardment by forces loyal to Moammar Gadhafi for the fifth straight day on Saturday. Rebel fighters in western Libya faced sustained artillery and rocket bombardment by forces loyal to Moammar Gadhafi for the fifth straight day on Saturday. In a packed classroom on a cool evening near the front line in Libya's civil war, 15-year-old Mira is teaching children to spell out the names of animals in the ancient Berber script, an act that once could have landed her in one of Gadhafi's jails. The indigenous people of north Africa, known to others as Berbers and among themselves as Amazigh, were brutally suppressed under Gadhafi, who considered the teaching of their language and culture to be a form of imperialism in his Arab country

– The US has recognized the Libyan rebels' National Transitional Council as the country’s legitimate government, CNN reports. “The United States recognizes the National Transitional Council as the legitimate government of Libya,” the State Department said in a statement. “The United States recognizes the TNC as the legitimate government of Libya.” The recognition could unlock billions of dollars in frozen assets, Reuters notes.

– Rebel forces routed Gadhafi’s troops from the oil town of Brega in the biggest boost of their campaign in weeks, spokesmen said on Monday. The government denied the claim. Meanwhile, Russia criticized the US and other countries that have recognized the rebel National Transitional Council as Libya’s legitimate government, saying they were taking sides in the civil war. Setting Russia apart from the West, Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov said nations that recognized the TNC were pursuing a “policy of isolation.” He suggested could undermine efforts to end the five-month war.

– Moammar Gadhafi’s government is ready to hold more talks with the US and with rebels trying to oust him, but the Libyan leader will not step down, a government spokesman tells Reuters. “We are ready to hold more talks with the United States,” he said, but “Gadhafi will not bow to the demands of the Libyan people.”

– Moammar Gadhafi says he will not step down as Libyan leader, even as the United Nations Security Council meets to discuss the country's post-Gadhafi future. "I will not step down, I will not give up, and I will not leave," Gadhafi told reporters in Tripoli, according to the Telegraph. He said the Libyan people will decide the country's future and he will not be a "wounded old man" like his father, who ruled for more than 40 years. Gadhafi said he would not negotiate with the UN Security Council, which has yet to formally recognize the anti-Gadhafi rebels.

– Libyan rebels say the gunmen who shot dead their military chief were militiamen allied with their struggle to overthrow Moammar Gadhafi, raising questions about divisions and lawlessness within rebel ranks. The death of Abdel Fattah Younes has exposed deep rifts among the forces trying to overthrow Gadhafi, Reuters reports, in apparent confirmation of deep rifts among the forces struggling to overthrow the Libyan leader.

– In the wake of the mass shooting at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School in Parkland, Fla., some are calling for civility in the wake of the tragedy. Speaking at a vigil for the victims at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School, Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School, in Parkland, Fla., Thursday night, Gov. Rick Scott spoke about the tragedy at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School, in Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School, in Parkland, Fla., and Gov. – The European Union has banned Syrian oil imports in a bid to put pressure on President Bashar al-Assad and stop the violence that has killed more than 2,200 people in six months of protests. The oil ban is a first for the EU, which takes about 95% of Syria's oil exports, the BBC reports. The UN says more than 2,200 people have been killed in Syria since the protests began.

– The UN Security Council is set to meet today to discuss a draft resolution that would impose sanctions on Syrian President Bashar al-Assad's regime if it continues its violent crackdown on protesters. The US, UK, France, Germany, and Portugal are backing the resolution, with the US abstaining from the vote. The draft resolution would impose an asset freeze and travel ban on Assad and his inner circle, as well as freeze all assets belonging to them in Syria.

– China and Russia vetoed a UN Security Council resolution condemning Syria over its crackdown on anti-government protesters today, the New York Times reports. The vetoes effectively killed the resolution, which would have condemned the Syrian regime's violent crackdown on protesters and called for the release of all political prisoners. Susan Rice, the US ambassador to the UN, walked out of today's meeting when Syria's envoy criticized the US.

– The Syrian Observatory for Human Rights says a human rights activist was killed by security forces in the city of Daraa on Sunday as protesters took to the streets there for the first time in four years. The group, which tracks violence in the country, says a man was killed and at least a dozen others injured when regime forces opened fire on protesters in the city's Baba Amr district, the BBC reports. The Observatory says security forces are believed to have also killed a human rights activist named Ammar al-Jazeera, who was reportedly among those killed in the Daraa attack.

– Mahmoud Ahmadinejad has condemned the Syrian government's violent crackdown on dissent, in his "most outspoken" comments yet, he told CNN. "Nobody has the right to kill others, neither the government nor its opponents," said the Iranian president, who has so far refrained from criticizing his ally Bashar al-Assad. The Syrian government has killed more than 1,000 people in its violent crackdown on dissent, according to human rights groups.

– The Arab League has sent a message to Syrian President Bashar al-Assad to "take the necessary measures" to protect civilians as government forces continue their bloody crackdown on protesters. The League's ministerial committee on the Syrian crisis also urged Damascus to "take the necessary measures" to protect civilians, reports the BBC. The Syrian Observatory for Human Rights says more than 40 people have been killed across the country today.

– Syrian troops have killed at least 19 protesters during demonstrations against the government, rights groups say. The latest deaths come a day after 27 people were killed in violence in Homs, the country's third-largest city. The government has also promised to withdraw troops from the streets, the BBC reports.

– Human Rights Watch is calling for the Arab League to suspend Syria for failing to protect its people in the wake of the bloody crackdown on protesters, the BBC reports. "It's a horror story. we are really in crisis," says HRW's Syria director. "We are calling on the Arab League to suspend Syria's membership for as long as Bashar al-Assad continues to kill his own people."

– The Arab League suspended Syria today over the country's bloody crackdown on protesters, and the Syrian government has said it will not attend today's meeting in Morocco. The Syrian government has said it will not attend. The decision comes after the Arab League's observer mission in the country was attacked yesterday. Turkey, which has been increasing its pressure on Syria, has condemned the attacks on its missions. "The future of Syria cannot be built on the blood of the oppressed," said Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan.

– Syria's foreign minister has warned that the nation's civil war could soon resemble a civil war, as government forces continue their violent crackdown on protesters. Sergei Lavrov said that all countries hoping for a peaceful solution to the crisis must call for a peaceful solution to Syria with the help of all parties to end the violence, al-Jazeera reports. The comments come after Syrian troops attacked a key military base.

– Tens of thousands of supporters of Syrian President Bashar al-Assad thronged in the capital of Damascus today to rally in his support, reports al-Jazeera. The Arab League, meanwhile, rejected Syria’s demand that it be allowed to amend its peace plan to allow in more Arab League monitors.

– The Arab League has imposed economic sanctions on Syria in response to the regime's violent crackdown on protesters, and the Syrian government has responded by opening fire on protesters in the city of Latakia, al-Jazeera reports. The crackdown continues, with the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights reporting that more than 30 people have been killed today. The BBC has a live blog on the League's decision here.

– The UN Security Council will meet tomorrow in New York to discuss the situation in Syria, but Russia will not be one of the members. The country's foreign minister has warned that Russia will be the "first to go" to the UN if Bashar al-Assad's regime fails to end the violence in Syria, the BBC reports. Russia has been one of Assad's closest allies since the collapse of the Soviet Union, and the BBC notes that Moscow has been under increasing pressure to distance itself from the Syrian president.

– Syria's Bashar al-Assad made a rare public appearance today, and he made clear that he's not about to step down. "Nobody can deny the seriousness of these plots," he said in his first public remarks in months. " external conspiracy is clear to everybody." The comments come as the death toll in the five-month-old uprising now stands at more than 500, reports the BBC.

– Syrian President Bashar al-Assad has granted a "general amnesty" for all crimes committed in the uprising that began 10 months ago, state media reports. The amnesty will apply to anyone who turned themselves in before the end of January, peaceful protesters, army deserters, and those who handed in unlicensed weapons. The news comes as the Arab League monitors were attacked in Damascus last night, al-Jazeera reports.

– Syria has rejected a call from Qatar for Arab troops to be deployed in the country, saying such a move would worsen the crisis, the BBC reports. Syria's foreign ministry said in a statement that such a move would only "inflame the situation and make it worse," according to al-Jazeera.

– The Arab League has called for a "national unity government" in Syria that would include the opposition in two months' time, reports the BBC. The move comes as the death toll in the 10-month-old Syrian uprising rose to at least 5,000, according to the BBC.

– The Arab League has suspended its monitoring mission in Syria because of the nation's increasing violence. The move comes as the UN Security Council considers a draft resolution against the regime of Bashar al-Assad, reports the BBC. The move comes as the Arab League plans to send a delegation to New York to address the council.

– Syrian security forces shot and killed the vice president of the Syrian Arab Red Crescent today as he drove from Damascus to the northwestern city of Idlib, the BBC reports. The Red Crescent says Abdulrazak Jbeiro was killed as he drove from the capital to the city of Idlib, one of the hotbeds of the uprisings against the regime of Bashar al-Assad.

– A Russian ship bound for Syria ran into bad weather at a Cypriot port and was forced to stop, officials say. The cargo on board, which was loaded with weapons, was found to be "dangerous" on board, the BBC reports. The weapons are believed to be anti-aircraft and anti-tank missiles. The find comes as the UN Security Council debates whether to adopt an Arab League plan calling for an end to violence in Syria.

– The Arab League has approved a resolution that would pressure Syrian President Bashar al-Assad to step down, reports the New York Times. The measure is expected to be put to a vote Friday. Russia, meanwhile, has threatened to veto the resolution if it is put to a vote, reports the BBC.

– Russia's foreign minister is in Syria today for talks with President Bashar al-Assad, and he's expected to push for an Arab League mission to monitor a peace plan. The visit comes after Russia and China vetoed a UN resolution condemning the Syrian government's violence against protesters. Russia's foreign minister says Syria is ready for a larger Arab mission to monitor peace efforts and set a date for a constitutional referendum, the BBC reports.

– The Arab League has decided to revive its mission in Syria after the "disastrous" failure to agree on a UN resolution on the country, UN chief Ban Ki-moon said today. He said the League has sought help from the UN, the BBC reports. The Syrian government, meanwhile, continued its assault on the city of Homs, killing at least 110 people today, according to the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights.

– Syrian rebels have the "right to use whatever means they saw fit to get rid of a cancerous regime," al-Qaeda's leader Ayman al-Zawahiri said in a video message today, urging militants in other countries to join the uprisings against Bashar al-Assad's regime. The Syrian opposition "should not rely on the Arab League or the West for help," he said, according to the BBC. "They have the right to use whatever means they see fit to get rid of this cancerous regime."

– The death toll in two days of clashes in Syria has hit nearly 200, the BBC reports. Two activist groups put today's toll at 84, most of them in the Idlib region in the west. The violence comes as the Arab League meets in Cairo to decide its next move in the Syria crisis. The head of the Arab League observer mission has resigned, the BBC reports. League Secretary General Nabil al- Arabi told its members in Cairo they had to move quickly to end the "vicious cycle of violence" in Syria.

– Bashar al-Assad has decreed that a referendum on the country's new constitution will take place on Feb. 26, reports the BBC. The move comes after the UN Security Council voted against a resolution calling for an end to the violence in Syria. China, meanwhile, is sending a senior envoy to Syria in a bid to find a peaceful resolution. The move comes a day after China voted against a UN resolution calling for an end to violence. The moment when the UN approved the resolution, which also calls on President Bashar al-Assad to resign, is the latest of several attempts to bring an end to the crisis. – The shelling that killed American Marie Colvin and a French photographer in the besieged Syrian city of Homs was an act of "shameful brutality" against civilians by the regime of Bashar al-Assad, President Obama said today. "This is yet another example of the shameless brutality of the Assad regime," he said in a White House press conference. Colvin, a Sunday Times reporter, is the second Western journalist to be killed in Syria this week. French photographer Remi Ochlik also died in the shelling of Baba Amr, and the BBC reports that two other foreign journalists were wounded in the attack. – The Red Cross has called off a plan to evacuate Syrian civilians from the flashpoints of Homs and Baba Amr after Syrian government forces continued their shelling of the Baba Amr neighborhood, the BBC reports. The Red Cross had been in talks with the Syrian government to get the trapped civilians out of the area, but the negotiations stalled yesterday. The Red Cross says it will resume talks next week.

– Syrian troops launched a ground assault on the Baba Amr district of Homs today, in what appears to be a bid to crush the rebellion against President Bashar al-Assad's regime, the BBC reports. The Free Syrian Army says it has left Baba Amr after weeks of shelling. The Syrian National Council, the main opposition group, says it has formed a military bureau to unify armed resistance to the government. The group says it will bring armed groups under a central command and control the flow of weapons to avoid "chaos."

– The Red Cross has been unable to access the hard-hit Baba Amr area of Syria's Homs for a third day, but it has started handing out food and blankets to people who have fled the area, the BBC reports. He lashed out at Kofi Annan's call for talks, saying it was "disappointing" that the Syrian opposition was being " massacred every day."

– Kofi Annan's mission to broker a ceasefire in Syria got off to a rocky start today when Bashar al-Assad's regime rejected his offer of political dialogue. The two were expected to meet later today with UN and Arab League officials. Annan's goal is to get both sides to stop the fighting and allow humanitarian aid into the country.

– Syrian tanks rolled into the Baba Amr district of the city of Homs today, in what appears to be a bid to crush the last resistance to President Bashar al-Assad, reports the BBC. The district has been a hotbed of violence since the uprisings began more than a year ago. The Syrian Observatory for Human Rights says more than 40 people have been killed today. The news comes as UN-Arab League envoy Kofi Annan meets with opposition leaders in Turkey.

Annan is due to meet with Vladimir Putin later today.

The Syrian president "has accepted the plan but says terrorism must stop as well," according to state media. Annan's spokesman says the deadline for Syria to implement the plan has now passed. "The deadline is now," he said.

– The UN's observer mission in Syria got off to a violent start today when government forces opened fire on protesters in the Damascus suburb of Arbeen, the BBC reports. At least four people were killed, according to the opposition Syrian National Council. The violence comes a day after the UN's envoy for Syria, Kofi Annan, met with Bashar al-Assad in Damascus. Annan said he hoped the meeting would result in a "moratorium" on the violence, which he called a "milestone" in the peace process.

– The UN's observer mission in Syria is now called UNSMIS, the BBC reports. The mission is seen as the last hope for a political solution to the crisis, and many in the US and other countries are skeptical about the effectiveness of the observer mission. "The elections are a farce and will not change anything in the situation in the country," a spokesman tells the AP.

The Syrian Observatory for Human Rights says several people were injured by tear gas and live ammunition in the biggest protests there since the revolt began.

The clerics were opposing the regime of President Bashar al-Assad, and their deaths sparked clashes between pro- and anti-Syrian groups in the Lebanese capital.

– The UN Security Council has called an emergency meeting for tomorrow to discuss the horrific Houla massacre, in which at least 90 people, including many children, were killed by Syrian troops and pro-regime thugs, the BBC reports. British Foreign Secretary William Hague called for "an emergency meeting of the UN Security Council in order to address the appalling killing in Houla," which he called a "tragedy for the people of Syria and a flagrant violation of international law."

– The Syrian Observatory for Human Rights has released a list of more than 100 civilians it says have been killed by security forces in the past 24 hours, the BBC reports. The list includes 42 children and 18 women, all of whom are believed to have been summarily executed by security forces. The Syrian Observatory for Human Rights says more than 100 people have been killed in the past 24 hours. The list was released as the UN Security Council prepares to meet tomorrow to discuss the situation in Syria.

– Syria is officially in full-scale civil war, a UN official said today, after the Houla massacre claimed the lives of at least 109 people, many of them children, al-Jazeera reports. "Our anger at the Houla massacre was indescribable," said President Bashar al-Assad, who has denied government involvement in the attack.

– The Free Syrian Army has pulled out of the UN-brokered ceasefire in Syria, saying it's no longer committed to it, Reuters reports. The rebel group says at least 80 Syrian soldiers were killed in clashes and attacks on security forces checkpoints over the weekend. The Syrian Observatory for Human Rights says more than 100 soldiers have also been killed in the suburbs of Damascus and Idlib province. The Free Syrian Army is no longer committed to the nominal ceasefire in Syria, a spokesman has said.

The monitors were not injured in the shooting but have pulled back for the night, the BBC reports.

The group says at least 40 people were killed in a government airstrike on a rebel-held town, al-Jazeera reports. The Syrian Observatory for Human Rights says the airstrike targeted a funeral procession for a military defector who had been killed earlier in the day.

The comments come as government and rebel forces continued to pound Homs with mortars and snipers, the New York Times reports. The Syrian Observatory for Human Rights says more than 100 people have been killed across the country today, including 30 in Homs.

"We stand ready to work with all parties to assist with bringing an end to the violence," says the head of the observer mission. The move comes a day after the UN Security Council condemned the killing of more than 100 civilians in the Syrian city of Homs. The UN has also called on both sides to allow the evacuation of women, children, elderly, and injured civilians, reports the BBC.

Russia and China are among the world's most reluctant to intervene in Syria, but Fabius said the countries would "reach out to Russia and China ... demand that they get off the sidelines."

Annan warned that the conflict could spread across the region if the violence is not stopped, the BBC reports.
