– China is boosting its coastal forces by adding ships and 6,000 personnel by 2020, state media said today, a move likely to raise tensions with neighbors staking rival claims to waters thought to hold vast reserves of oil and gas.
– If Bashar al-Assad doesn't start talking to the opposition soon, Syria will "slip into civil war and spark regional conflict," says Bashar al-Assad's cousin, who lives in London.
– Jack in the Box has become the latest fast-food chain to pull toys from kids' meals, reports Reuters. McDonald's and Yum Brands, which owns KFC, have also pulled toys from kids' meals.

– The UN Security Council is set to hold an emergency meeting today to discuss Syria—and Russia's continued support of Bashar al-Assad. Russia's foreign minister warned last week that the West would be "left behind" if it continued supporting Assad.

– Tens of thousands of demonstrators took to the streets in Syria today, defying a military crackdown, as the three-month uprising against President Bashar al-Assad's rule entered its fourth week. One human rights lawyer tells Reuters that 24 civilians were killed today.
– Moammar Gadhafi's forces have captured the town of Jedaim in western Libya, Reuters reports. Gadhafi's JANA state television reported that the capture of the town of Jedaim was announced today.

– New York City will open its clerk's offices Sunday to allow same-sex couples to wed on the first day the state's gay marriage bill goes into effect, reports Reuters. City clerk's offices in the five boroughs normally are closed on weekends.

– Divers searching a Russian river boat which sank in the Volga over the weekend said they saw more than a hundred bodies trapped inside. Russia suffered one of its worst shipping disasters when passenger liner, the Admiral Nakhimov, hit the cargo ship Pyotr Vasev off the Black Sea port of Novorossiysk, reports Reuters.
– Saudi Arabia, the United Arab Emirates, Kuwait, and Qatar have launched a military operation to cut off oil supplies to Syria and Yemen, in an effort to stem the unrest there, Reuters reports.

– At least 30 people were killed over the weekend in factional fighting between Syrian residents in the flashpoint city of Homs, according to the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights. Syrian troops and militiamen killed 16 people in attacks in Homs yesterday, including 10 mourners at a funeral.

– Mohamed Bin Hammam, who tried to become the first Arab to become president of soccer's governing body, has been banned for life. Bin Hammam, a 62-year-old Qatari, was found guilty of trying to bribe delegates in his bid to run for the presidency of FIFA.
– Hosni Mubarak's trial has been postponed until next week—at least for now—so that he and Mubarak can be tried together. Click here for more on Mubarak's trial.
– If you're looking for a safe place to park your money during the financial crisis, look no further than Britain, according to a Reuters poll of 14 investment managers.

– Bashar al-Assad gave his first speech since the Syrian protests began two weeks ago today, and in it, he promised to reshuffle his Cabinet and allow journalists and human rights activists into the country, reports Reuters.
– An amateur video purports to show protesters removing the body of a dead man and the aftermath of shelling in the Syrian city of Hama, reports Reuters.

– Syrian tanks rolled into the Baba Amr neighborhood of Hama today, making good on the regime’s threat to use heavy weapons on densely populated civilian areas, reports the New York Times. “They are coming in large numbers,” said one Hama resident. “They are coming from Baba Amr and from outside the Baba Amr.”

– The Dow Jones Industrial Average plunged more than 500 points today, dropping below 12,000 for the first time since the financial crisis, reports MarketWatch. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq dropped below 5,000 as well.
– Syrian troops continued their shelling of the northern city of Latakia today, witnesses tell Reuters, as the death toll there climbs to 31—including a 2-year-old girl killed yesterday.

– The UN Security Council is set to hold a rare emergency meeting today to discuss Syria, reports the New York Times. The meeting comes as the death toll in the five-month-long unrest nears 100, with more than 100 killed yesterday.
– A member of the Royal Air Force's Red Arrows aerobatic team was killed today when his plane crashed at an air festival in England, reports Reuters.

– The fall of Moammar Gadhafi isn’t going to bring an end to NATO’s involvement in Libya, NATO Secretary-General Anders Fogh Rasmussen said today. “We will continue to protect our European allies,” he told reporters, according to Reuters.
– Bashar al-Assad hosted an iftar meal for Islamic leaders yesterday—and it was attended by none other than Moammar Gadhafi himself, Reuters reports.

– Japan’s Fukushima Dai-ichi plant has been seriously damaged by the massive earthquake and ensuing tsunami, but officials say they’re making progress in getting the plant under control, the New York Times reports. “We have been unable to stabilize the situation at the Dai-ichi nuclear plant as of yet, and we have decided to make further efforts to stabilize the situation by releasing as little radiation as possible,” a government official told reporters. “We have decided to release as little radiation as possible so that people can return home as quickly as possible.” Experts believe that if the quake and ensuing tsunami had been more powerful, it would have caused far more damage.

– The UN General Assembly has wrapped up a two-day meeting in New York that was dominated by the Arab Spring uprisings and the Arab-Israeli conflict. UN Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon, who opened the meeting by calling for an immediate end to hostilities, said he was "saddened" by the violence and called for an immediate end to hostilities, the AP reports. He said he had instructed his aides to find a way out of the crisis as soon as possible.

– Yemen’s top generals and ambassadors have defected to call for the resignation of President Ali Abdullah Saleh. “We call on the government to stop the violence and allow the people to freely choose their leaders,” said General Abed Rabbo Mansour al-Hadi, according to al-Jazeera. “We don’t want a civil war in Yemen.” The defections came as protests against Saleh’s 32-year rule spread to Syria, where security forces opened fire on thousands of mourners who marched at the funeral of a 23-year-old killed by security forces yesterday.

– The death toll in six days of protests in Syria rose to at least 37 today, according to the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights. The latest protests were centered in the southern city of Daraa, where security forces opened fire on hundreds of people marching in solidarity with the protests, according to al-Jazeera.

– The UN Security Council will meet tomorrow to discuss the situation in Syria, where protests have been raging for more than two weeks and security forces have killed at least six people over the last two days, reports the New York Times. UN Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon said he was "shocked" by the violence and called for an immediate end to it, but stopped short of calling for the resignation of President Bashar al-Assad. Hillary Clinton, meanwhile, said in a TV interview that the situation in Syria is different from the situation in Libya.

– A rare edition of the King James Bible had been sitting on a ledge in a village church in England for the past 150 years, barely touched and much less read, until a printing error made it one of only a few still in existence. The edition that had been sitting on the ledge in the pretty Anglican church in Wiltshire, central England for the past 150 years, barely touched and much less read, is one of only a handful that still exists

– Syria's military is packed with members of President Bashar al-Assad's Alawite minority, reducing any pressure on him to stand aside if protests grow, military experts say. Senior Syrian army ranks are packed with loyal members of Assad's Alawite minority, reducing any prospect of military pressure on him to stand aside if protests grow, military experts say. Unlike the armies in Tunisia and Egypt, whose refusal to confront violent protests spelt the demise of their autocratic rulers, the fate of many senior Syrian military officers is closely tied to that of Assad," notes the New York Times.

– Protests broke out across the Arab world today, the Muslim day of prayer, with demonstrators killed in Syria and Yemen while Egyptians staged one of the biggest rallies since Hosni Mubarak's fall. Syrian security forces killed 17 pro-democracy demonstrators and two were shot dead in Yemen. Japan announced power reduction targets for Tokyo and north Japan that will require big manufacturers and other large users to cut peak summer consumption by one— fourth as it vowed to avoid rolling blackouts that could hobble the economy.

– Lewis Hamilton led from start to finish at yesterday’s Malaysia Grand Prix, but had to fend off Jenson Button on the last lap. It was the British driver’s third-place finish in the first three races of the season, but his fourth-place finish wasn’t quite as impressive. Button had been in the lead for most of the race, but spun on the last lap as he tried to pass Kobayashi on the outside. The Williams driver finished eighth, his best result of the season.

– Manchester United will play AC Ajaccio for a place in the Champions League final after beating Chelsea 2-0 at Old Trafford last night. A first-half goal from Rio Ferdinand proved to be the difference as United advanced on the away-goals rule 3-1 from the first leg. The Red Devils will play AC Ajaccio for the title on May 19.

– A grisly video showing the beheading of an Australian aid worker in the Gaza Strip has sparked outrage among human rights groups, the Guardian reports. The grisly video, which purports to show 26-year-old Gifty McCool being beaten, blindfolded, and sliced in the head with a knife, was released by Hamas after the grisly killing last week. McCool, who worked for an Australian charity in Gaza, was tortured and killed by masked gunmen after being found with bloodied hands and feet.

– Russia won the Fed Cup for the first time in three years today, defeating Italy in the final after Francesca Schiavone and Flavia Pennetta dropped out of the team. Italy had been the favorites to win the competition for the third year in a row. But Schiavone and Pennetta pulled out of the team's captain's meeting ahead of their match against Vera Zvonareva and Vinci criticized the decision, the Telegraph reports.

– Ronnie Farquhar, Reuters’ Cold War correspondent who was on the spot when the Soviets put down the anti-Communist uprising in Hungary in 1956, has died at the age of 88 in Geneva. Born in Scotland, Farquhar joined Reuters in 1952 and covered the Cold War from every East European capital and Beijing in the 1950s and 1960s.

– Syrian security forces killed almost 90 protesters today, according to rights activists—the bloodiest day in a month of escalating pro-democracy demonstrations against the rule of President Bashar al-Assad. The Local Coordination Committees sent Reuters a list with the names of 88 people, classified by region, the group said; most were killed in areas stretching from the port city of Latakia to Homs, Hama, Damascus, and the southern village of Izra'a. The army deployed overnight in the flashpoint city of Homs, witnesses said, ahead of today prayers that have been marked by intensifying protests in the last five weeks against authoritarian rule. The prayers will test whether President Bashar al-Assad's decision Thursday to lift emergency law, imposed by his Baath Party when it took power in a coup 48 years ago, will defuse mass discontent with repression and corruption.

– Libya’s ambassador to the UK had been invited to the wedding of Prince William and Kate Middleton, but Britain has decided not to invite him due to the country’s current conflict, according to official sources. An invitation to Libya’s ambassador was prepared before the conflict in the country intensified in March but was not delivered, according to the sources.

– Syrian security forces opened fire on protesters today, in the first reported use of force since the uprising began six weeks ago, according to the New York Times. The violence came as opposition leaders met in Turkey, where they pleaded for international help, Reuters reports. “Our friends in the West, in Turkey, in the Arab world, if they want to help us, then they can do that,” said opposition leader Burhan Ghalioun.

– China released its first comprehensive review of the country's demographics in a decade yesterday, the first comprehensive review of the country's demographics in a decade. Population experts have been warning that China could face potentially disastrous social and economic problems as the population ages and the number of Chinese of working age shrinks Britain's Prince William and his wife Catherine drove past with his new bride in a vintage Aston Martin convertible after their wedding reception. (Prince William surprised well-wishers with a James Bond moment outside Buckingham Palace on Friday.)

– The Navy SEALs who took down Osama bin Laden in a raid on a compound in Abbottabad, Pakistan, didn’t just kill the al-Qaeda leader, they killed more than 100 of his friends and relatives, the New York Times reports. “We took out more than 100 of his friends and relatives,” says a senior Navy official. “We killed more than that.” Friends of bin Laden’s who lived in the Abbottabad area tell the Times they were surprised by the raid. “We didn’t expect this,” says one. “We didn’t expect to kill him. We didn’t expect to kill him in front of his family. We didn’t expect to kill him in front of his wives and children.”

– Syrian security forces killed 23 protesters today, according to one human rights group, as the European Union imposed sanctions in response to the government's bloody crackdown on pro-democracy demonstrators. The latest protests were in the cities of Daraa and Douma, where demonstrators burned the Syrian embassy in Greece, and in the capital of Manama, where security forces opened fire on thousands of protesters. The New York Times notes that the protests are the biggest so far in the Arab world. Vietnam has sent troops to contain a rare protest by ethnic Hmong Christians, some of whom were calling for an independent kingdom, diplomatic and other sources tell Reuters. The demonstration by as many as 7,000 people in the far— flung mountains of Dien Bien Province, near the northwestern border with Laos and China, began several days ago, but details were scant from the hard—to-access region.

– NATO kept up the pressure on Moammar Gadhafi's forces today, pounding Libyan government targets with more airstrikes, but the stalemate has presented Western powers with a dilemma as to whether to offer covert aid to the rebels. Rebels said that four times during the day NATO bombed government weapons depots around 30 miles southeast of Zintan, a town in the Western Mountains region where conflict is escalating Kuwait, not Syria, to run for the UN.

– Syria's military opened fire on protesters today, in the first reported use of force since the protests began seven weeks ago, according to the New York Times. “We opened fire because people were throwing stones at the security forces,” one human rights activist told the Times. “The security forces then opened fire on them.” The military has been standing by President Bashar al-Assad since the protests began, but today's action appears to be an attempt to intimidate protesters.

– A 28-year-old Syrian man says he trekked 130 miles from the Golan Heights to Tel Aviv by hitching a ride with Israeli soldiers and riding a bus alongside them. Hassan Hijazi says he entered Israel from Syria over the weekend during a protest against Israel's separation from the Palestinian Authority. He says he hitchhiked his way to the Israeli city of Jaffa, then rode a bus to Tel Aviv, where he turned himself in today, the AP reports.

– The Obama administration has slapped sanctions on Syrian President Bashar al-Assad's regime, as well as his inner circle, accusing the government of continuing its bloody crackdown on protesters. The penalties include an arms embargo, visa bans and financial restrictions, and an arms embargo on the country's central bank, the New York Times reports. "The United States is prepared to impose additional sanctions if Bashar al-Assad fails to meet his international commitments to reform his regime," the White House said in a statement.

– Dominique Strauss-Kahn’s defense team has hired a PR firm run by former CIA officers in an attempt to bolster its case against the former IMF chief, the New York Times reports. The firm, DC-based Greenberg Traurig, has worked with Bill O’Reilly and others in the past. Strauss-Kahn’s defense team hasn’t said what it plans to do with the firm.

– A NATO airstrike on Moammar Gadhafi's compound in Tripoli caused plaster to fall from the ceilings of a hotel where foreign reporters were staying, Reuters reports. The strike was the heaviest yet on Gadhafi, and came as the US said the Libyan leader would "inevitably" be forced from power.

– Libyan rebels have rejected Moammar Gadhafi’s offer of a cease-fire, saying it’s only a stalling tactic to get NATO to stop airstrikes. NATO, meanwhile, said it would continue to strike Gadhafi’s forces. South African President Jacob Zuma will visit Libya next week for talks with Gadhafi, Reuters reports.

– Syrian President Bashar al-Assad today granted a general amnesty to all members of political movements, including the Muslim Brotherhood, following 10 weeks of protests. The amnesty covers “all members of political movements, including the Muslim Brotherhood,” state television said, according to Reuters.

– Brazil's state-controlled oil company, Petrobras, says it will boost oil production by 25% this year as it adds a new platform to an offshore field, Reuters reports. The Marlim Sul field, located off Brazil's coast, currently produces around 200,000 barrels of oil a day. The company plans to boost production to 300,000 barrels a day by the end of the year.

– China's Li Na became the first Asian to win the French Open today, defeating Italy's Francesca Schiavone in straight sets. Li became the first Chinese player to win a Grand Slam title, notes the AP, and the first Asian to do so in women's tennis.

– Britain, France, Germany, and Portugal have handed the UN Security Council new sanctions against Syria, upping the pressure on Bashar al-Assad's regime to end its bloody crackdown on protesters. The sanctions, which include freezing all assets belonging to the Syrian government and banning visas for Syrian officials and their relatives, were unanimously approved by the five veto-wielding members of the Security Council, the New York Times reports. Turkey, meanwhile, opened its borders to thousands of refugees fleeing Syria's violence, Reuters reports.

– The UN Security Council will meet tomorrow in an emergency session to discuss the situation in Syria, which has been rocked by protests for three months. The last such meeting was in April, but this will be the first time the UN Security Council has met since the uprisings began. Syria will be a major topic of the meeting, according to one Western diplomat. “We are expecting the UN Security Council to meet,” he told Reuters. “We expect the Syrian government to stop the violence and allow the political process to begin.”

– China isn’t happy with the Obama administration’s plan to let American companies do business in China. “We are opposed to the US administration’s plan to allow American companies to do business in China,” the country’s foreign ministry said today, according to the Wall Street Journal. “We are opposed to the US administration’s plan to allow American companies to do business in China.”

– China plans to boost its coastal forces by adding ships and 6,000 personnel by 2020, state media said today, a move likely to raise tensions with neighbors staking rival claims to waters thought to hold vast reserves of oil and gas. The expansion of the China Maritime Surveillance Agency, a paramilitary law enforcement agency that patrols China's territorial waters, was unveiled two days after the country sent its largest civilian maritime patrol ship to the South China Sea. Reuters has more.

– Syria's uprising could lead to civil war if Bashar al-Assad doesn't start talking to opposition leaders soon, according to a cousin of the Syrian president. "We are talking to him, but we can't talk to him," said Ribal al-Assad, who lives in London and is one of the most prominent dissidents in Syria. "We can't talk to him. We can't talk to his inner circle. They are controlling him." He said religious extremists were taking over the uprising and that a corrupt inner circle was keeping Assad from making concessions.

– Jack in the Box has become the latest fast-food chain to ditch the toys in kids' meals. The California-based chain, which has been under pressure from regulators and public health advocates to ditch marketing of unhealthy food to children, has pulled all toys from its kid's meals in Los Angeles, a company spokesman tells Reuters. McDonald's and Yum Brands, which owns KFC and Taco Bell, have also ditched toys in kids' meals.

– The UN Security Council will meet tomorrow to discuss the situation in Syria, but Russia will likely use its veto to block any resolution that would explicitly call for the resignation of President Bashar al-Assad. Russia's ambassador to the UN, Vitaly Churkin, told reporters today that any such resolution would be "premature," according to the AP.

– Syrian forces killed 24 civilians on Friday, a prominent rights lawyer said, as tens of thousands of people called on President Bashar al-Assad to step down in some of the biggest demonstrations since a three-month uprising began. Defying Assad's military crackdown, demonstrators took to the streets again after Friday prayers across the country, from towns near the western Lebanese border to the desert regions near Iraq in the east

– Moammar Gadhafi's forces have launched an attack on the oil port of Ras Lanuf, 60 miles southeast of the capital Tripoli, in an apparent attempt to cut off fuel to the rebels who have taken over much of the country's east, the New York Times reports. Gadhafi's forces have also launched attacks on Zawiyah, just south of the capital, and on Kikla, south of the capital. There have been no reports of casualties so far.

– New York City will open its clerk's offices on Sunday, July 24, to allow same-sex couples to wed on the first day the state's gay marriage bill goes into effect, officials said on Wednesday. City clerk's offices in the five boroughs of New York normally are closed on weekends, but Mayor Michael Bloomberg said that for this special occasion they will be open.

– Divers searching a Russian river boat which sank in the Volga at the weekend said they saw more than a hundred bodies trapped inside. In 1986 Russia suffered one of its worst shipping disasters when passenger liner the Admiral Nakhimov, hit the cargo ship Pyotr Vasev off the Black Sea port of Novorossiysk

– The UN Security Council is set to meet tomorrow to discuss the situation in Syria, where protests have killed more than 200 people this year. Syria's ambassador to the UN, Bashar al-Assad, will attend, according to a French newspaper report picked up by Reuters. The report says Iran is offering Syria $5.8 billion in aid.

– At least 30 people were killed over the weekend in factional fighting between Syrian residents in the flashpoint city of Homs, according to a rights group. Syrian troops and militiamen killed 16 people in attacks in the city yesterday, including 10 mourners at a funeral for 10 people killed by security forces on Monday, according to activists. The Arab League's chief visited Syria yesterday to discuss the "necessity of reform," but refused to give details of his meeting with President Bashar al-Assad.

– Mohamed Bin Hammam has been banned from soccer for life for attempting to bribe delegates in the Caribbean to vote for him in the FIFA presidential election. The 62-year-old Qatari was found guilty of attempting to bribe delegates in the Caribbean to vote for him. FIFA's ethics committee, found guilty of trying to bribe delegates in the Caribbean to vote for him in the FIFA presidential election, has been left with his reputation in tatters and a 29 years career as an administrator over mass protests against President Bashar al-Assad in Hama and elsewhere.

– Hosni Mubarak’s trial has been postponed until next week at the earliest, so that he can be tried alongside his son Gamal, Reuters reports. The ruling followed a weekend of clashes involving protesters demanding swifter reforms and faster prosecution of Mubarak and his officials.

– If you're looking for a safe place to park your money in the midst of the European debt crisis, look no further than Britain, according to a Reuters poll. The poll of 14 investment managers found that the average allocation to UK stocks jumped 3 percentage points in July, while the average allocation to global stocks rose 3 percentage points. The reason? Britain's relatively cheap debt.

– A judge in Guatemala has sentenced four soldiers to 6,060 years in prison each for a 1982 massacre during the country's 36-year civil war. More than 200 people were killed when Guatemalan soldiers attacked the northern village of Las Dos Erres in 1982 at the height of Guatemala's civil war. This is the first conviction for a massacre during the country's civil war, according to Reuters.
– Amateur video purports to show protesters removing the body of a dead man and the aftermath of shelling in the Syrian city of Hama. (See it here.)

– Syrian tanks rolled into the Baba Amr neighborhood of Hama today, encountering little resistance, according to the New York Times. “The streets are empty,” said one resident. “The sounds of gunfire can be heard.” The Syrian Observatory for Human Rights says more than 30 have been killed in the latest violence, but the Times notes that the death toll is likely to rise as security forces continue to surround Hama. “The situation is getting worse by the day,” said a human rights activist. “The situation is getting worse by the hour.”

– The protests that have rocked the Middle East and North Africa over the last few weeks have been largely peaceful—but that could be changing. “The situation is getting worse by the day,” one activist tells the New York Times. “The situation is getting even worse by the hour.” The latest protests have been taking place in Egypt, Libya, Yemen, and Bahrain, as well as in Libya, where security forces have launched a major crackdown on the opposition. “The situation is getting worse by the day,” one activist says. “The situation is getting even worse by the hour.”

– Syrian forces continued their shelling of the northern port city of Latakia today, in the third day of a military assault aimed at crushing protests against President Bashar al-Assad. The Syrian Revolution Coordinating Union, a grassroots activists group, said three people, including a 22-year-old man, were killed in the city today, bringing the civilian death toll there to 31—including a 2-year-old girl.

– The UN Security Council is set to meet tomorrow to discuss new sanctions against Syria, as the death toll in the five-month uprising rose to more than 3,000, according to the New York Times. The latest: Turkey's prime minister likened the situation in his country, which borders Syria, to Libya's civil war, and said he was "frustrated" by Bashar al-Assad. Russia, which has been selling weapons to Syria, said it would continue to do so, Reuters reports.

– A member of the Royal Air Force's Red Arrows aerobatic team was killed today when his plane crashed at an air festival in England, reports Reuters. The 33-year-old pilot was killed when his plane went down near an airport some 100 miles from London.

– The fall of Moammar Gadhafi is likely to lead to an increase in Western attention to Syria and protests against Bashar al-Assad, according to the New York Times. “The demise of Gadhafi is likely to lead to an increase in Western attention to Syria and to the protests against Bashar al-Assad,” one political analyst tells Reuters.
– Bashar al-Assad hosted an iftar meal for Syrian leaders last night, and one of the attendees was none other than Moammar Gadhafi. Reuters has the video.

– Japan's newly elected prime minister, Yoshihiko Noda, named his new finance minister today, Reuters reports. Jun Azumi, a 49-year-old former parliamentary affairs chief, had been the frontrunner for the job, but his first choice turned him down. Noda, a former finance minister, has been Japan's sixth prime minister in five years.

– The prime minister of Iraq's semi-autonomous Kurdish region was killed in a suicide bombing yesterday, making him the first prime minister killed in combat since Nouri al-Maliki took office in 2003, the AP reports. Nouri al-Maliki was killed by a roadside bomb as he left his office in Baghdad. Nouri al-Maliki had been expected to run for re-election this month.

– Arab League chief Nabil Elaraby said he had agreed a series of measures with President Bashar al-Assad today to help end violence in Syria, as activists said Assad's forces killed six people in their relentless crackdown on dissent. Elaraby said he would present the proposed measures to Arab foreign ministers who are due to discuss Syria's five-month uprising against the Syrian president and his military assault on protesters. Syrian forces shot dead six pro-democracy protesters today, according to the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights.

– The UN Security Council is set to meet tomorrow to discuss the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, but Turkey's prime minister wants the whole world to rally behind the Palestinian flag. "We want the Palestinian flag to be raised over the United Nations," Tayyip Erdogan told reporters, according to Reuters. "We want all Arab and Islamic states to raise the Palestinian flag over the United Nations."

– Ireland beat Australia 15-6 in a humdinger of a Tri- Nations match today, ending the Aussies' hopes of a record 23rd straight victory. The Irish front row squeezed the life out of their Australian counterparts in the scrum, leading to a number of penalties which flyhalf Jonathan Sexton and Ronan O'Gara kicked to claim a 15-6 victory.

– Turkey has suspended talks with Syria and may impose sanctions, Prime Minister Tayyip Erdogan said, the clearest sign yet that Ankara has parted ways with President Bashar al-Assad over his bloody crackdown on anti-government protesters. After long maintaining close relations with neighbor Syria, Turkey has spoken out increasingly against Assad, urging him to end a military crackdown on a popular uprising and to launch democratic reforms, reports Reuters.

– Pope Benedict held a surprise meeting today with victims of clerical sexual abuse, saying his "deep regret" for their suffering, the Vatican said. The meeting came on the second day of Benedict's four-day trip to Germany, where record numbers of Catholics have officially left the faith in protest at clerical abuse, and where the church faces some 600 requests for compensation.

– The number of hospitals offering new moms free infant formula samples has dropped dramatically over the last few years, according to a new report by Reuters Health. But the drop is still big enough to worry experts, who worry that the free samples could undermine official recommendations that new moms stick to breastfeeding until their baby is at least six months old.

– The UN Security Council will meet tomorrow in an emergency session to discuss the situation in Syria, according to a statement from New York Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon. The Security Council has already condemned the killing of more than 30 civilians by security forces and pro-regime forces, but this will be the first time it will address the situation on the ground, reports the New York Times. Syria has been relatively peaceful in the uprising against President Bashar al-Assad, but sectarian conflict could destabilize the country, according to Reuters.

– Syria's newly formed opposition group is calling on the international community to take action to protect the country's people from the regime's violent crackdown. The National Council rejected foreign intervention that compromises Syria's sovereignty, but said the outside world had a humanitarian obligation to protect the Syrian people, reports Reuters.

– Turkey said today it would impose sanctions on Syria despite the blocking of any UN resolution condemning Bashar al-Assad’s regime for its bloody crackdown on protesters, Reuters reports. “We will impose sanctions on Syria based on the decisions taken by the UN Security Council,” Turkey’s deputy prime minister told reporters. “We will impose sanctions on Syria based on the decisions of the Turkish government.” Turkey has been one of the most vocal critics of the UN resolution, and its decision to conduct a military exercise in the southern province of Hatay, where more than 7,000 Syrians have taken refuge, may coincide with a visit from Prime Minister Tayyip Erdogan to refugee camps in Hatay after he returns from South Africa this week.

– Syrian security forces opened fire on tens of thousands of mourners at the funeral of a Kurdish opposition figure today, killing at least two people, activists said. The funeral of Meshaal al-Tammo in the eastern Syrian city of Qamishli turned into a protest against President Bashar al-Assad, with mourners chanting anti-Assad slogans and calling on him to step down Russian Prime Minister Vladimir Putin visited China on Tuesday in his first foreign trip since revealing plans to reclaim Russia's presidency, addressing a challenging relationship with a giant neighbor whose growth is both an opportunity and a potential threat for Moscow. Meanwhile, the most senior officer to defect from Syria's armed forces said there is no option but to topple Assad by force and he was directing a military uprising against the Syrian leader from within Turkey, reports Reuters.

– The Swedish state-owned power group Vattenfall has begun the sale of electricity networks and heat distribution assets in Finland and has approached potential buyers, the group's Finnish manager said. The development comes as the UN Security Council prepares to meet tomorrow to discuss Syria. Western nations are not doing enough to pressure Russia into changing its stance on Syria, the figurehead for the Syrian National Council said on Friday. Paris-based Burhan Ghalioun, considered the group's de facto leader, told France 24 television the newly formed SNC hoped to get recognition from European countries once its structure is in place.

– Syrian security forces opened fire on a funeral procession in central Damascus today, killing three mourners and injuring 20. The violence came as the Arab League decided not to suspend Syria from the organization, instead urging the government and opposition to negotiate an end to the violence. “We will call all of the parties of the opposition and government to hold a dialogue within 15 days,” the League’s secretary general told reporters.

– Syrian tanks swept into the flashpoint city of Homs today, in one of the bloodiest crackdowns of the uprising, activists say. At least 25 people were killed, one of the highest single-day death tolls so far in the seven-month uprising, according to the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights. Turkey's foreign minister held his first meeting with Syrian opposition leaders last night, urging them to use peaceful means despite what activists say was the biggest offensive yet in the city of Homs by forces loyal to President Bashar al-Assad. Ahmed Davutoglu's discussion with the opposition Syrian National Council last night, reported by an unnamed Turkish foreign ministry official, followed a threat by Syria to deal firmly with any country which formally recognizes the council.

– The body of one of Moammar Gadhafi’s sons has been found in a drainpipe outside his hometown of Sirte, reports Reuters. Saif al-Islam Gadhafi, 69, was found in a hole in the side of the drainpipe, along with the body of his youngest son Mutassim, reports the Telegraph. Saif al-Islam Gadhafi had been holed up in the Gadhafi compound for more than a week.

– European Union leaders have given Iran until the end of the year to respond to concerns about its nuclear program or face tougher sanctions. They also threatened to tighten restrictions on Syria if Bashar al-Assad's regime continues to repress its population, Reuters reports. “We expect Iran to engage in constructive and substantial talks with Western powers to bring about a negotiated solution to the nuclear question,” said European Council President Herman Van Rompuy.

– Bashar al-Assad met with an Arab League committee on Syria today, but emerged without much progress, according to the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights. “The meeting did not reach any decisions,” an Arab League official told Reuters. “It was just a meeting of committee members.” At least 20 people were killed today, according to the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights; nine soldiers were killed by armed rebels, and 11 civilians were killed by army gunfire.

– The International Criminal Court has issued an arrest warrant for Moammar Gadhafi, accusing him of crimes against humanity during the conflict in Libya. Gadhafi's eldest son, Saif al-Islam, has already surrendered to Libyan authorities, but the younger Gadhafi remains holed up in the Sahara Desert, fearing he will be killed by his own people, reports Reuters.

– Syrian tanks rolled into the city of Deir al-Zor today, in what appears to be the first significant military action since the uprising began more than a month ago. “The situation in Deir al-Zor is changing quickly,” one opposition leader told the AP. “The army is coming and they are coming in large numbers, and they are firing on the people.” The Syrian Observatory for Human Rights says more than 30 people have been killed in the fighting, bringing the total death toll since the uprising began to more than 3,000. In other developments: NATO ruled out military intervention in Syria today, but said Damascus should draw lessons from Libya, where NATO backed rebels won a civil war that resulted in the killing of long-serving leader Moammar Gadhafi. Western powers have been tightening sanctions on Syria but have shown no appetite to repeat their Libyan operation in the Middle Eastern nation where protesters have demanded outside protection from a crackdown that has killed 3,000 people. – The Red Cross is pressing Syrian authorities for wider access to thousands of detainees arrested in pro-democracy protests, while insisting that its own strict terms be met. In an interview with Reuters, Jakob Kellenberger, president of the International Committee of the Red Cross, said that the independent humanitarian agency would assess its role after an upcoming visit to a detention center in Aleppo.

– Syrian tanks rolled into the flashpoint city of Homs today, in one of the bloodiest crackdowns of the eight-month uprising. Activists say more than 100 people have been killed in the city, which has been under attack since Friday, according to the New York Times. The violence comes just days after the Arab League said Syria had accepted a peace plan that would remove its troops and police from cities and allow peaceful protests.

– The Arab League suspended Syria today over the country's bloody crackdown on protesters, and called on the army to stop killing civilians. Syria's representative to the Arab League said the move violated the organization's charter and showed it was "serving a Western and American agenda," reports Reuters. Hours after the League's decision, hundreds of Assad supporters armed with sticks and knives attacked the Saudi Arabian embassy in Damascus and Turkish and French consulates in the city of Latakia, residents said.

– Syrian army defectors launched an attack on the country's intelligence headquarters in Damascus today, in the first such assault since the Arab League suspended the country yesterday. The attack, which Reuters describes as a "high-profile assault," targeted the building's computer network and storage facilities. The Syrian National Council, an opposition group, said the attack was in response to the Arab League's threats to slap economic sanctions on the country unless President Bashar al-Assad complies with the Arab League's peace plan.

– With the Arab League deadline for Syria to end its bloody crackdown looming, President Bashar al-Assad told Britain's Sunday Times that "the conflict will continue and the pressure to subjugate Syria will continue." Assad blamed militants for the violence, and said the government's role is to fight them, protect civilians, and restore stability. Turkey, meanwhile, has contingency plans in place to protect civilians in neighboring Syria if the violence worsens, Reuters reports.

– Japan's Fukushima Dai-ichi plant is leaking radioactive steam for the first time since the disaster struck, but officials say they're making progress in getting the plant under control, Reuters reports. They say they've managed to avoid a complete meltdown, but that it's too early to say whether they'll be able to avoid a full meltdown. "We have succeeded in putting the steam out of the reactor once again," a government spokesman said. "But we are doing everything we can to avoid a complete meltdown."

– The Supreme Court will rule Friday on whether President Obama's health care law is unconstitutional, Reuters reports. If the court sides with the Obama administration, it would be the first time the law has been declared unconstitutional since the 1970s. If the court sides with the Obama administration, it would be the first time the law has been declared unconstitutional by a Republican-controlled Congress.

– With protests rocking the Arab world for days, Yemen's president has made his most defiant statement yet, warning that the country could plunge into civil war if he is forced to resign. President Ali Abdullah Saleh, who has been in power for 32 years, says he will not leave office until he has been replaced by a vice president, according to al-Jazeera. The statement comes after top generals, ambassadors, and some tribes backed the protesters, Reuters reports.

– Syrian security forces opened fire on hundreds of protesters today, killing at least four, after the funeral of a soldier killed in yesterday's violence. In the southern city of Daraa, security forces fired on hundreds of people marching in solidarity with the protesters, who have been staging demonstrations for six days, al-Jazeera reports.

– Protesters took to the streets in Syria for the second straight day today, despite the presence of the army, which has deployed for the first time in the country's key port city of Latakia, Reuters reports. At least five people were killed today, according to the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights, which says more than 100 have been injured. The news comes a day after security forces killed at least six people when they fired on protesters in the southern city of Deraa.

– Syria's Bashar al-Assad addressed the nation today for the first time since the uprisings began two weeks ago, and he made clear that he's serious about reform, reports Reuters. "I believe that the future of Syria is in the hands of the people," he said. "I will do everything in my power to protect the country and its people." In his first public appearance since the uprisings began, Assad said he's opened talks with opposition leaders.

– Syria's army is packed with members of President Bashar al-Assad's Alawite minority, reducing any prospect of military pressure on him to stand aside if protests grow, military experts say. Senior Syrian army ranks are packed with loyal members of Assad's Alawite minority, reducing any prospect of military pressure on him to stand aside if protests grow, military experts say. Unlike the armies in Tunisia and Egypt, whose refusal to confront non-violent demonstrations spelt the demise of their autocratic rulers, the fate of many senior Syrian military officers is closely tied to that of Assad.

– With protests raging across the Arab world, Egypt's interim president has called for an end to the violence, Reuters reports. In a televised address to the nation today, Mohamed ElBaradei called for an end to the violence, which he says has killed more than 200 protesters since the fall of Hosni Mubarak. "We will no longer tolerate the killing of peaceful protesters," he said, calling for the release of all political prisoners.

– Lewis Hamilton won the Malaysia Grand Prix today, his fourth victory in five races this season. Hamilton started on the front row and led for most of the race, but ran off the track at turn 4 on the final lap. It was the first time in his career he'd led more than a lap, according to Reuters. Hamilton's team says it's looking at upgrades to his car, but it's not clear whether they'll be in time for tomorrow's race.

– Manchester United will play AC Ajaccio for a place in the Champions League final after beating Chelsea 2-0 at Old Trafford last night. A first-half goal from Anderson proved to be the difference as United advanced on the away-goals rule 3-1 on the night. The Red Devils will play AC Ajaccio for the title on May 19.

– A grisly video of the beheading of a German aid worker in the Gaza Strip has gone viral. The video shows the man, identified as 26-year-old Stefan Hessel, being beaten, blindfolded, and dragged from a house by masked gunmen, reports Reuters. Hessel's body is then shown in a pool of his own blood. Hamas officials say he was killed because he was spying for Israel.

– Russia won the Fed Cup for the first time in three years today, defeating Italy in the final after Francesca Schiavone and Flavia Pennetta dropped out of the team. Italy's Roberta Vinci, who lost to Russia's Vera Zvonareva in the first match, criticized her teammates' decision to bail on Schiavone and Pennetta, who were both injured, Reuters reports.

– Ronnie Farquhar, a Reuters journalist who covered the Cold War for more than 50 years, died today in Geneva at the age of 88, Reuters reports. Farquhar's career with the news agency began in 1952 and he covered every East European capital and Beijing in the 1950s and 1960s.

– Syrian security forces killed almost 90 protesters today, according to rights activists—the bloodiest day in a month of escalating pro-democracy demonstrations against the rule of President Bashar al-Assad. The Local Coordination Committees sent Reuters a list with the names of 88 people, classified by region, who were killed in areas stretching from the port city of Latakia to Homs, Hama, Damascus, and the southern village of Izra'a. In other Syria news: The army deployed overnight in the flashpoint city of Homs, witnesses said, ahead of today prayers that have been marked by intensifying protests in the last five weeks against authoritarian rule. The prayers will test whether President Bashar al-Assad's decision Thursday to lift emergency law, imposed by his Baath Party when it took power in a coup 48 years ago, will defuse mass discontent with repression and corruption.

– Libya won’t be sending a representative to the wedding of Prince William and Kate Middleton this week. An invitation to Libya’s ambassador was prepared before the conflict in the country intensified in March but was not delivered, according to official sources, who tell Reuters that Britain has decided against inviting a Libyan representative to the wedding.

– With the bloodshed mounting in Syria, the EU is considering sanctions against the regime of President Bashar al-Assad, Reuters reports. EU foreign policy chief Catherine Ashton says the possible sanctions would include an oil embargo and an arms embargo, as well as a travel ban and freezing of Syrian assets. Syria's ambassador to the EU says he has been barred from attending Friday's wedding of Prince William and Kate Middleton because of the nation's bloody crackdown on protesters.

– China has released its first complete population report in a decade, and it's not good news for the world's most populous country. The Communist Party estimates that the country's population will shrink from 1.3 billion to 1.3 billion by 2050, Reuters reports. The country's working-age population will shrink from 50.7 million to 50.3 million by the year's end, according to state media.

– The Navy SEALs who killed Osama bin Laden aren't just "good soldiers," they're "good marines," Defense Secretary Leon Panetta says. In an interview with NBC's Meet the Press, Panetta said the SEALs went after bin Laden not because they wanted to kill him, but because bin Laden had been threatening the US for years, Reuters reports. – Syria's bloody crackdown on protesters continued today, with human rights groups reporting that security forces killed at least 23 protesters, according to Reuters. The news comes as the European Union imposed sanctions on Syria in response to President Bashar al-Assad's bloody crackdown, and Vietnam sent in troops to contain a rare protest by ethnic Hmong Christians, some of whom were calling for an independent kingdom.

– Libyan rebels say NATO bombed a number of government weapons depots today, as the stalemate in the conflict shows no sign of abating. Rebels say four airstrikes hit weapons depots southeast of Zintan, a town in the Western Mountains region where conflict is escalating Kuwait, not Syria, to run for the UN, Reuters reports.

– Syria's military opened fire on protesters today, in what appears to be the first significant use of force by the nation's security forces since the protests broke out seven weeks ago, the New York Times reports. At least three people were killed, according to the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights, which says more than 100 have been injured. The military has been known to fire on protesters before, but this is the first time the military has used live ammunition since the uprisings began, according to the Times.

– A 28-year-old Syrian man who broke into Israel over the weekend says he hitchhiked his way to Tel Aviv, then rode a bus with Israeli soldiers to the city. “It was my dream to reach Jaffa,” Hassan Hijazi said on Israel’s Channel 10 TV, according to the Jerusalem Post. Hijazi, who says he works for the Syrian intelligence service, says he entered Israel by pushing through an Israeli border fence with a group of Palestinian protesters.

– The Obama administration has ramped up sanctions against Syria in the wake of the nation's bloody crackdown on protesters, Reuters reports. The sanctions include an asset freeze and visa ban on top Syrian officials, including President Bashar al-Assad's father-in-law, Maher Hafez al-Assad.

– Dominique Strauss-Kahn’s defense team has hired a PR firm run by former CIA officers in an attempt to boost the former IMF chief’s chances of acquittal in the sexual assault case against him, the Wall Street Journal reports. Washington consulting firm Greenberg Traurig has been tasked with crafting a public-relations strategy for the case, which is currently in the hands of a New York judge.

– With NATO's air strikes targeting Moammar Gadhafi's inner circle and security forces, the Libyan strongman's grip on power appears to be loosening. Gadhafi's eldest son today told state TV that his father's grip on power is " loosening by the hour." Saif al-Islam Gadhafi said his father's grip on power is " loosening by the hour" because of the strikes, according to Reuters. Saif al-Islam Gadhafi said his father's grip on power is " loosening by the hour because of the crusader aggression and the aggression of the traitors."

– South African President Jacob Zuma will visit Tripoli next week for talks with Moammar Gadhafi, the presidency said in a statement on Wednesday. South Africa's Talk Radio 702 earlier reported that the aim of the visit was to discuss an exit strategy for Gadhafi, but the presidency statement made no mention of that, Reuters reports.

– Syria's Bashar al-Assad has granted a general amnesty to all members of political movements, including the Muslim Brotherhood, after 10 weeks of protests, state television said today. The amnesty covers “all members of political movements, including the Muslim Brotherhood,” it said, according to Reuters.

– Brazil's state-controlled oil company, Petrobras, says it will boost oil production by 25% this year, to 300,000 barrels per day, Reuters reports. The company, known as Petrobras, says it has built a new platform that will boost production from the offshore Marlim Sul field by the end of the year.

– China's Li Na became the first Asian to win the French Open today, defeating Italy's Francesca Schiavone in straight sets. The sixth-seeded Li became the first Chinese player to win a Grand Slam tournament, notes Reuters.

– The UN Security Council is set to hold an emergency meeting today to discuss the violence in Syria, reports Reuters. Syria's ambassador to the UN, Bashar al-Assad, says the council will discuss imposing a no-fly zone over the country. The news comes as the death toll in Syria's uprising rose to more than 3,500, according to al-Jazeera.

– With the death toll mounting in Syria's three-month uprising, the Obama administration is edging closer to sanctions against Bashar al-Assad's regime. Britain's Prime Minister David Cameron has asked the EU to review sanctions against Syria, which could include freezing Syria's assets, Reuters reports. Syria's central bank, meanwhile, said today that the nation's currency has lost half its value since the uprising began, according to al-Jazeera.

– China's central bank has cut the amount of money it will lend to banks for the first time in more than three years, Reuters reports. The bank cut the amount of money it will lend to banks by 41% to 58.9 billion yuan, or about $8.2 billion, from April's record high of 92.4 billion yuan. The move comes as the central bank tries to cool torrid growth in the country's money supply.

– With the price of food soaring, the G20 has agreed to monitor world supplies to prevent a repeat of last year's food crisis, according to a draft statement seen by Reuters. The group will also work to prevent speculation from driving up food prices, the statement says. China will boost its coastal forces by adding ships and 6,000 personnel by 2020, state media said today, a move likely to raise tensions with neighbors staking rival claims to waters thought to hold vast reserves of oil and gas. The expansion of the China Maritime Surveillance Agency, a paramilitary law enforcement agency that patrols China's territorial waters, was unveiled two days after the country sent its largest civilian maritime patrol ship to the South China Sea.

– If Bashar al-Assad doesn’t start talking to protesters soon, Syria could plunge into civil war and spark regional conflict, according to a cousin of the Syrian president. “There is a real risk of civil war if there is no political dialogue between the government and the protesters,” said Ribal al-Assad, who lives in London. Bashar’s “inner circle is controlling him,” he added, according to Reuters.

– Jack in the Box has become the latest fast-food chain to ditch toys for kids' meals, Reuters reports. The California-based chain started pulling toys from its kids' meals on Thursday, according to a company spokesman. McDonald's, Burger King, and Wendy's have already pulled toys from kids' meals, according to the Huffington Post.

– Bashar al-Assad's forces killed more than 100 protesters today as they swept through the Baba Amr district of Homs, activists tell Reuters. The army opened fire when protesters tried to march on a military base, according to a Human Rights Watch report cited by al-Jazeera. The news comes a day after the UN's High Commissioner for Human Rights called for an end to the violence.

– Syrian forces killed 24 civilians on Friday, a prominent rights lawyer said, as tens of thousands of people called on President Bashar al-Assad to step down in some of the biggest demonstrations since a three-month uprising began. – Libyan rebels say they've seized a key town from Gadhafi's forces and are closing in on the capital, Tripoli, reports Reuters. They've taken the town of Jedaim, about 100 miles south of the capital, and say they're closing in on Gadhafi's compound in Tripoli's Jedaim neighborhood. Rebels say they've seized a stockpile of weapons from Gadhafi's forces, including surface-to-air missiles, anti-tank missiles, and rocket launchers.

– New York City will open its clerk's offices Sunday, July 24, to allow same-sex couples to wed on the first day the state's gay marriage bill goes into effect, officials said on Wednesday. City clerk's offices in the five boroughs of New York normally are closed on weekends, but Mayor Michael Bloomberg said that for this special occasion they will be open.

– Divers searching a Russian river boat which sank in the Volga over the weekend said they saw more than a hundred bodies trapped inside. The boat was traveling from the Black Sea port of Novorossiysk to the city of Nizhny Novgorod when it was hit by a cargo ship and sank, according to Russian news agencies. More than 100 people were killed.

– Iran's supreme leader has offered Syria billions of dollars in aid in an attempt to end the country's bloody uprising, a French newspaper reported today. Ayatollah Ali Khameini made the offer in a meeting with Syrian Foreign Minister Walid Moallem, according to Le Parisien, which cited a report from a Tehran think tank linked to Iran's leadership. Syria's uprising has killed more than 5,000 people since March.

– The Arab League's chief has arrived in Syria to discuss the country's bloody uprising with President Bashar al-Assad, reports Reuters. Arab League chief Nabil Elaraby, who met with Assad last week, declined to give details of his meeting with the leader, but was quoted by media as saying the League did not accept "outside interference in the internal affairs of the Arab countries."

– World soccer's governing body has banned Mohamed Bin Hammam for life for attempting to bribe delegates in the Caribbean to vote for him as president of FIFA. Bin Hammam, a 62-year-old Qatari, was found guilty of trying to bribe delegates in the Caribbean to vote for him in the FIFA presidential election. FIFA's ethics committee started proceedings against him earlier this year after it was revealed that he had tried to bribe Caribbean soccer officials to vote for him.

– Hosni Mubarak's trial has been postponed until next week—at least for now—so he'll be tried alongside his sons, Alaa and Gamal, Reuters reports. Mubarak's attorneys argued for the delay, saying they needed more time to prepare, according to al-Jazeera.

– If you're looking for a safe place to park your money during the market's volatility, look no further than Britain, according to a Reuters poll. The poll of 14 investment managers found that the average allocation to UK stocks rose 3 percentage points in July, while the average allocation to global stocks rose 3 percentage points. The reason for the shift? worries about sovereign debt problems in Europe and the US.

– Four soldiers were sentenced to 6,060 years in prison today for a 1982 massacre that marked the end of Guatemala's 36-year civil war, Reuters reports. More than 200 people were killed when soldiers attacked the northern village of Las Dos Erres. – An amateur video purports to show protesters removing the body of a dead man and the aftermath of shelling in the Syrian city of Hama, according to Reuters.

The district is a longtime bastion of support for Bashar al-Assad, and it's not clear whether the army will try to retake it. – The Dow Jones Industrial Average plunged more than 500 points today, dropping below 12,000 for the first time since the financial crisis, as investors fretted about the health of the US economy, reports MarketWatch. The Dow opened down about 50 points.

– Syrian tanks rolled into the port city of Latakia today, in the third day of an assault aimed at crushing protests against President Bashar al-Assad, witnesses and activists tell Reuters. The death toll in Latakia now stands at 31, including a 2-year-old girl killed yesterday.

The UN Security Council will hold a rare emergency meeting tomorrow to discuss the crisis, Reuters reports. In other Syria news: Turkey's prime minister likened the situation to Libya, and urged Russia to stop selling weapons to Syria, but Moscow says it will go ahead with the sale, according to Reuters.

– A member of the Royal Air Force's Red Arrows aerobatic team was killed today when his plane crashed at an air festival on the coast of England, Reuters reports. The 33-year-old pilot was killed when his plane went down near an airport some 100 miles from London.

– The fall of Moammar Gadhafi has brought an end to more than 40 years of instability in Libya, but the dictator's 42-year rule could be short-lived, according to an analysis by the New York Times. Gadhafi's forces still control much of the western part of the country, and there's no guarantee they'll be able to hold off rebel fighters who have now taken control of the capital of Tripoli. "The fall of Gadhafi does not mean the end of Libya," one analyst tells Reuters. "But it does mean the end of an era."

– With the fall of Moammar Gadhafi, Syria's Bashar al-Assad has been forced to flee the country, according to opposition leaders. “The situation in Syria is getting worse by the day,” a spokesman for the opposition Syrian National Council tells Reuters. “The situation is getting worse by the hour,” he said, adding that Gadhafi's exit will encourage other dictators to follow suit.

– The Dow Jones Industrial Average plunged more than 500 points in early trading today on fears that Europe's debt crisis will hit the US economy hard, Reuters reports. At one point, the Dow was down more than 500 points, though it recovered some ground.

– Arab League chief Nabil Elaraby says he's reached an agreement with Syria's Bashar al-Assad that will be presented to Arab foreign ministers today. "We have agreed on a series of measures to end the violence," Elaraby said after meeting with Assad, according to Reuters. "The measures will be discussed by the Arab League's foreign ministers."

– Syria's Bashar al-Assad has been ordered to step down as president by the country's military council, CNN reports. The move comes after the council's leader, General Abdel Fattah Younis, announced his resignation earlier this week. Younis had earlier said he would step down by the end of the month. Syria's decision to accept Younis' resignation is expected to be announced today, according to al-Jazeera. Younis had said he would step down if Bashar al-Assad didn't resign by the end of the month. – Ireland beat Australia 15-6 today to become the first team to beat the Wallabies in Brisbane since 1983. "It's the proudest moment of my career," said captain Brian O'Driscoll. "We've worked so hard for this and to get the win is a massive achievement." The Wallabies had the better of the first half and led 6-0 at the break, but Ireland hit back with three penalties from Jonathan Sexton and one from Ronan O'Gara.

– Turkey has suspended talks with Syria and may impose sanctions, Prime Minister Tayyip Erdogan said today, the clearest sign yet that Ankara has parted ways with President Bashar al-Assad over his bloody crackdown on anti-government protesters. Turkey has long maintained close relations with Syria, urging him to end a military crackdown on a popular uprising and to launch democratic reforms, Reuters reports. European governments have acted vigorously in recent weeks to tighten the sanctions on Assad in hopes of reining in his bloody crackdown on protesters, which has killed some 2,700 people in six months. Syria's oil exports have come to a standstill due to sanctions and this may force a cut in production, weakening President Bashar al-Assad's ability to generate cash but not threatening his grip on power yet, traders and analysts say.

– Pope Benedict met privately with victims of clergy sex abuse in Germany today, expressing his “deep regret” for their suffering, the Vatican said. The meeting came on the second day of Benedict’s four-day trip to Germany, where record numbers of Catholics have left the faith in protest at clerical abuse, and where the church faces some 600 requests for compensation, Reuters notes.

– The trend of hospitals handing out free infant formula samples is on the wane, according to a new report from Reuters. In 2007, more than 90% of US hospitals gave out such samples, but that figure has dropped to less than 50% today, according to the report. The reason for the drop-off? Fewer hospitals are offering the samples, and experts worry that giving them to new moms could undermine official recommendations that they stick to breastfeeding until their baby is at least six months old.

– With the uprising against Bashar al-Assad's rule entering its seventh week, the Free Syrian Army says it's prepared to fight to the death for the country's independence. "We will not kneel, we will not surrender, and we will not leave," an army spokesman tells Reuters. "We are ready to fight until the last man, until the last woman, until the last bullet." The Free Syrian Army says it's now in control of more than 90% of Syria, according to the AP, but it's not clear whether it will be able to maintain its grip on much of the country. In other Syria news: Tanks and helicopters continued to pound Rastan today, in the first major battle with defecting soldiers since the uprising began, according to residents. At least 1,000 deserters and armed villagers have been fighting tank—and helicopter—backed forces trying to regain control of Rastan, a town of 40,000, in central Syria.

– Syria's newly formed opposition group is calling on the international community to take action against President Bashar al-Assad's regime, Reuters reports. The Syrian National Council rejected foreign intervention that compromises Syria's sovereignty, but said the outside world had a humanitarian obligation to protect the Syrian people.

– Turkey says it will impose sanctions on Syria even after the UN Security Council blocked sanctions against Bashar al-Assad's regime, Reuters reports. Turkey's prime minister, who returned from South Africa yesterday, is expected to visit refugee camps in the southern province of Hatay, where more than 7,000 Syrians have taken refuge, according to Reuters.

– The highest-ranking officer to defect from Syria's army says he's directing a military uprising against President Bashar al-Assad from within Turkey. Riad al-Asad, who is now living under Turkish government protection in Hatay province on the Syrian border, said some 15,000 soldiers, including officers, had already deserted, and he was waiting to move his command inside Syria, according to Reuters. Turkey is piling pressure on Syria with border military exercises, economic sanctions, and the harboring of Syrian opposition groups and army defectors, but Ankara must tread carefully to avoid arousing the suspicion of Arab states or spurring Syrian counter- measures.

– With the Olympics canceled, London officials are looking for new tenants for the city's stalled Olympic stadium, Reuters reports. West Ham United, a London soccer club, is in the running, but it's not clear whether they'll be able to afford the $1 billion price tag for the 80,000-seat stadium, which has been mired in legal challenges since the city was awarded it for the 2012 games.

– Syrian forces opened fire on a funeral procession in central Damascus today, killing three mourners and injuring 20, according to the Syrian state news agency. The violence comes a day after President Bashar al-Assad lifted a state of emergency and promised parliamentary elections by February. In other Syria news: Assad has formed a committee to draft a new constitution in four months, according to the official news agency.

– The Arab League has decided not to vote on whether to remove Syria from its charter, despite the nation's bloody crackdown on protesters. The decision was made after Syria's foreign minister met with the opposition Syrian National Council and urged them to use peaceful means to end the violence, Reuters reports. Turkey, which recognizes the council, has warned Syria that it will deal firmly with any country that recognizes it.

– In the wake of Moammar Gadhafi's death, the Arab world is grappling with how to best mark his demise.
