– BP's first-quarter net profits doubled from a year earlier, but the oil giant's shares fell as investors worried about the impact of the widening oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico and the company's ability to cover it, the Wall Street Journal reports. BP's share price fell 4.5% to $47.30 in early trading.

– Louisiana shrimpers have filed a class-action lawsuit against BP and other defendants in the Gulf of Mexico oil spill, the first claim for economic losses stemming from the disaster, Reuters reports. Transocean and Halliburton also named as defendants. The lawsuit was filed on behalf of all coastal Louisiana interests. BP shares fell 7% on Thursday after the oil company said a leaking well in the Gulf was gushing at five times the rate initially thought. Fishermen and tourism businesses in the northeast Gulf of Mexico are dreading the nightmare possibility that a huge oil spill could wreck their livelihoods if it reaches shore. The threat could not come at a worse time as the oyster season ends and shrimp season is set to begin.

– BP's chief executive says the company won't enforce the terms of contracts it has with fishermen helping clean up the oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico. Alabama's attorney general has accused BP of trying to buy the state's fishermen off by waiving their right to sue the company in the wake of the spill, the AP reports. BP's contracts with Alabama fishermen say that if they refuse to help clean up the spill, the company will pay them less than it costs to repair the damage.

– The scope of the oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico is just beginning to become clear, with Thad Allen saying today that it could take at least a few days to know for sure how much oil is pouring into the ocean. “I'm sure it's going to be at least a day or two before we know the full extent of the leak,” he said on ABC’s This Week, according to the Wall Street Journal. “It's so big. It's going to be a day or two before we know the full extent of the leak.” BP said today that it had captured some of the oil, but that it would take a few days to know for sure.

– BP's latest attempt to contain the oil in the Gulf of Mexico has hit a snag, and the company says it will take 48 hours to assess the problem and come up with a new plan, reports the Times-Picayune of New Orleans. The company said in a statement that the cost of the spill so far is 350 million dollars, a figure that analysts tell Reuters suggests the final bill could be much higher.

– The Justice Department is investigating whether Transocean, owner of the drilling rig that exploded last month in the Gulf of Mexico, misled Congress about the risks of drilling in deep water, the Wall Street Journal reports. Transocean told Congress that conditions were "more favorable" for drilling in deep water than in shallow water, according to documents obtained by the Journal.

– The Obama administration's latest estimate of the amount of oil gushing from BP's ruptured well in the Gulf of Mexico is actually much higher than the 5,000 barrels the White House had said it would use, reports the Washington Post. The administration had said it would use 6,000 barrels a day. But the real figure is closer to 20,000 barrels a day, says a White House official who spoke on condition of anonymity. The administration's estimate of 5,000 barrels a day is a "massive underestimate," writes Justin Gillis at New York. "The stated reason for not getting a better figure is weak indeed: A spokesman for BP, David H.OTTAWA— Exasperated Canadian legislators grilled the head of BP Plc Canadian unit on Thursday, concerned about the risks of the company's plans to drill in Arctic waters after the catastrophic Gulf of Mexico oil spill. But Anne Drinkwater, president of BP Canada, offered few answers at a hearing at Parliament's Standing Committee on Natural Resources on the safety of drilling in the Far North."

– BP's latest attempt to contain the oil spilling in the Gulf of Mexico has so far only succeeded in siphoning some of the oil, but the US Coast Guard says it's likely to take at least a week to plug the well. The Coast Guard's point man on the situation, Thad Allen, said today that it could take at least a day to know for sure whether BP's latest plan worked, reports the New York Times. "We're not sure what we're going to get," he said. "We're not sure it's going to work. We're not sure it's going to be effective. We're not sure it's going to be long-term." BP said today that it may be able to stop the oil flow permanently within a week, reports Reuters.

– President Obama today blamed BP for the widening oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico and promised a full investigation into the cause of the disaster. “We’re going to bring to justice those responsible for this spill,” Obama said in his weekly radio address. “BP is responsible for this spill.” Obama also said that offshore oil drilling could only go forward if there were assurances that such accidents wouldn’t happen again, notes Reuters.

– The feds are ready to do whatever it takes to make sure BP pays for the massive oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico, a top official tells the New Orleans Times-Picayune. “We're going to do everything in our power to make sure that BP pays for the cleanup,” said Thad Allen, the Coast Guard's top official in the region. “We're not going to let them off the hook.” BP insists it's doing everything it can to contain the oil, but it's running into trouble on two fronts, notes the Wall Street Journal. First, it's running into trouble on two fronts: The federal government has asked BP to install an expensive shut-off valve on the well, but the company says it's not ready. Second, it's running into trouble on two fronts in Alaska, where the Trans-Alaska Pipeline was shut down yesterday after several thousand barrels of oil spilled into backup containers.

– BP's latest attempt to plug the gushing oil well in the Gulf of Mexico didn't work as well as it could have, according to the Coast Guard's report on the night of the explosion. The five-day review found that the blowout preventer didn't work as it should, and that the blowout preventer itself didn't work as it should, the New Orleans Times-Picayune reports. The Coast Guard's report also states that BP failed to install an expensive shut-off valve on the well, the Washington Post reports. The blowout preventer is a key piece of equipment that's supposed to shut off the flow of oil if something goes wrong, but it didn't work as it should, the Times-Picayune notes.

– BP's latest attempt to plug an oil well in the Gulf of Mexico didn't work, and the company's chief operating officer said today that the company will move on to another option, Reuters reports. "We have not been able to stop the flow," Doug Suttles said. "We have made the decision to move on to the next option." BP shares dropped sharply in after-hours trading today, reports the Wall Street Journal.

– With oil pouring into the Gulf of Mexico and BP's latest attempt to plug it foiled, some are calling for a new logo for the oil giant. "Does BP's now—familiar yellow—and—green sunflower logo need an update?" asks Joe Daley, founder of logo clearinghouse logodesigners.com. "It's time for BP to change its corporate image," he tells Reuters. Director James Cameron, who made two documentaries about the wreck of the Titanic and the 1997 Hollywood movie using remotely operated underwater vehicles, was on hand for a brainstorming session with scientists, academics, and Washington officials on Tuesday, environmental sources say. Cameron made two documentaries about the wreck of the ocean liner Titanic as well as the blockbuster 1997 Hollywood movie using a small fleet of specially designed remotely operated underwater vehicles.

– BP's latest attempt to contain the oil gushing in the Gulf of Mexico appears to be working, the company said today. It captured 10,500 barrels, or about 439,950 gallons, in 24 hours, and a second containment system should be in place within 24 hours, the company said. But that's not good enough, President Obama warned today. “My understanding is that BP has contracted for $ 50 million worth of TV advertising to manage their image during the course of this disaster,” he said, according to Reuters.

– President Obama says he wants to know “whose ass to kick” over the Gulf oil spill, adding to the pressure on energy giant BP as it seeks to capture more of the leak from its gushing well. In an interview with NBC News, Obama also said that if BP Chief Executive Tony Hayward worked for him, he would have fired him by now over his response to the 50 years-old spill, the worst environmental disaster in US history. “I want to know who’s responsible for this, and I want to know that the American people know exactly who’s responsible for this,” Obama said. “My job is not to be Tony Hayward’s replacement. My job is to know who’s responsible for this oil spill.” BP shares fell 14% to a 14-year low on the news.

– As the oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico threatens to become one of the biggest environmental disasters in US history, BP is scrambling to contain the spread of oil—and it's bought up terms like "oil spill" from Google and other search engine providers to help people find it, the Telegraph reports.

– President Obama will press BP executives this week to set up an escrow account to pay damage claims by individuals and businesses hurt by the Gulf oil spill disaster, the AP reports. The move comes as Obama, who will address the nation about the spill on Tuesday night, faces questions on his handling of the disaster, which was in its 55th day State officials say they are feeling the effects, both environmentally and financially, and that they need much more than what BP is offering to recover lost wages and taxes. Florida Attorney General Bill McCollum sent a letter to BP on Thursday requesting that the company deposit $ 2 BP's name is so besmirched in DC that restoring its old Anglo-Iranian Oil Company moniker could hardly worsen things.

– BP CEO Carl Svanberg apologized to the American people today for the massive oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico and said the company would freeze its dividend for the rest of the year. “We are deeply sorry for what has happened,” Svanberg told reporters after meeting with President Obama at the White House. “We’re going to pay for it.” Svanberg said the company would sell off some of its assets to pay for the spill, the Wall Street Journal reports. “We’re going to sell off some of our assets,” he said. “We’re not going to be paying dividends this year.”

– BP CEO Tony Hayward was spotted watching a yacht race off the English coast today, sparking new controversy in the United States as his company struggles to plug its huge Gulf of Mexico oil leak. A spokeswoman for the British energy giant said Hayward was spending time with his teenage son at the Isle of Wight boat race after devoting most of the past two months to the oil spill away from his family GRAND ISLE, Louisiana—Those on the front lines of the Gulf Coast oil spill say they are forced to fight two battles—one against the crude washing into lush wetlands and another against needless bureaucracy. As BP rushed to raise cash to pay for the Gulf oil spill, a partner in the out-of-control well said the British company was likely guilty of willful misconduct and should shoulder the financial burden for the worst US BPs chief executive Tony Hayward branded the most hated man in America may be surprised to find himself cast in the role of victim by a growing clan of web-based supporters on Facebook.

– BP's latest estimate of the amount of oil it's leaking in the Gulf of Mexico doesn't take into account cleanup efforts or the amount of oil it hopes to have collected by the end of today, the Wall Street Journal reports. The company estimates that between 60,000 and 100,000 barrels of oil have been spilled so far, with the total expected to be closer to 100,000 barrels by the end of today. BP plans to siphon some of the oil, but it's not clear whether that will be enough to cover the spill's costs.

– House Democrats are working on legislation to tighten rules on deep-water drilling, especially in the wake of the BP oil spill, Rep. Henry Waxman tells Reuters. “We're working on it,” the House Energy and Commerce Committee chairman said. Waxman's move comes as a new poll shows that President Obama's job performance has dropped to the lowest level of his presidency. His approval rating stood at 45% in the Wall Street Journal/NBC News poll, down 5 points from early last month.

– One of New Orleans’ most prominent chefs has filed a class-action lawsuit against BP, claiming the oil spill is damaging the city’s seafood industry. Susan Spicer is seeking class-action status on behalf of restaurants and others in the seafood industry, which has lost normal seafood supplies because of the spill, the Times-Picayune reports. Meanwhile, BP spent another 300 million on the Gulf cleanup effort in the last three days, bringing its total bill to 2.65 billion, Reuters reports.

– Tropical storm Alex slowed oil spill cleanup work in the Gulf of Mexico and drove more petroleum into fragile Gulf wetlands and beaches on Thursday, with any permanent fix to BP's ruptured deep-sea well still several weeks away, Reuters reports. More than 10 weeks into the crisis, oil continued spewing into the Gulf, clean-up success remained limited, and a proposal by the Obama administration to halt all deep-water drilling for the next six months remained in limbo.

– President Trump's tariff war with China appears to have hit a new low, with both sides blaming each other for the other's move, reports the Wall Street Journal. China has accused Trump of exaggerating the threat of a trade war between the two countries, while Trump says China is exaggerating the threat of a trade war of its own. The two sides have traded blame for each other's moves in the past, with Trump accusing China of trying to “snatch away” US jobs and China accusing Trump of exaggerating the threat of a trade war of its own.

– BP's latest attempt to contain the oil spill might not be as effective as it thought. The company's chief executive said today that it would take at least a day to plug the well, the Wall Street Journal reports. "We're not optimistic that we'll be in a position to do that today," Tony Hayward said. "We're going to have to deal with the blowout preventer first, and then we'll deal with the wellhead." Meanwhile, BP's latest plan to deal with the spill is to pump mud into the well, but it's not clear whether that's the best way to do it.

– BP's public relations department has set up a fake Twitter account, claiming to be from the oil giant, reports the Telegraph. The account—BPGlobalPR—tweets things like, "My expl of BP spill in The Black Swan II:  do n't give the manager of a nuclear plant an incentive bonus based on cost savings." Nassim N Taleb also got in on the action today, tweeting, "My expl of BP spill in The Black Swan II:  do n't give the manager of a nuclear plant an incentive bonus based on cost savings."

– BP's latest attempt to contain the oil in the Gulf of Mexico didn't work out so well, and the US Coast Guard has ordered the company to install a device that will capture most of the oil before a relief well can be completed, the Washington Post reports. The idea is to pump mud in from the top to plug the well, a process that could take up to a month. “We're pleased with our progress,” BP's senior vice president told reporters yesterday, according to Reuters.

– BP's new containment cap was able to slow the flow of oil into the Gulf of Mexico for the first time in more than three months today, reports the Wall Street Journal. President Obama called the development a "positive sign," but said more work needs to be done before the spill can be stopped.

– BP's latest attempt to plug its Gulf oil well appears to be working—at least for now. The company said today that it had managed to stop the flow of oil from the well for the first time since it was capped last week, reports the New York Times. "We're pleased to have stopped the flow of oil," said a BP spokesman. "It's a good day for BP and for the Gulf." He added that the company would keep testing the pipe until it was clear whether the procedure had worked, reports Reuters.

– Kenneth Feinberg, the administrator of BP's $20 billion compensation fund for victims of the Gulf oil spill, says the company is holding up payments. “I have a concern that BP is stalling claims,” Feinberg tells Reuters. “We’re going to move as quickly as we can. We’re not going to slow down. We’re going to move as fast as it takes to stop the flow of oil.” Adjusters in Louisiana and other Gulf states are on high alert for fraud as they pass out emergency funds to compensate residents for spill-related losses. Swindlers, scammers and even a few strippers are flocking to the Gulf Coast in search of a piece of the $20 billion BP has set aside to compensate residents for spill-related losses.

– BP's new CEO, Bob Dudley, says the company will set up a $20 billion fund to compensate victims of the Gulf oil spill and will take a “haircut” on assets to help pay for it, the Wall Street Journal reports. Dudley, who was appointed just last week, says the money will come from BP’s shareholders, not from the federal government. “We’re going to raise the money,” he tells the BBC. “We’re not going to pay the bill on BP’s behalf. We’re going to pay the bill for the people who have been harmed, for the businesses that have been damaged, and for the states that have been affected.”

– The BP oil spill has put a renewed focus on Norway's plans to open up more of its Arctic waters to oil and gas drilling. The country, which has long favored drilling in the region, has postponed a decision on drilling off the coast of the Lofoten and Vesteraalen archipelagos until next year at the earliest, Reuters reports. Norway's powerful oil industry says it needs to tap resources off the Barents Sea border region with Russia to continue Norway's oil boom amid dwindling North Sea output.

– BP's chief executive says the cost of dealing with the massive oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico will likely be much higher than the $4.5 billion the company originally estimated it would need to pay, the Wall Street Journal reports. Tony Hayward said today that the cost of cleanup will likely be "in the neighborhood of $1.5 billion to $3 billion." He added that he doesn't expect the spill to have an impact on BP's financial results for the rest of the year. BP's share price dived 6% in early trading today on the news.

– The "dead zone" at the bottom of the Gulf of Mexico has now covered 7,722 square miles—about the size of Massachusetts—and overlaps areas hit by oil from BP's broken Macondo well, scientists say. The area of hypoxia, or low levels of oxygen, covered 20,000 square miles and extended far into Texas waters, according to researchers from the Louisiana Universities Marine Consortium. The dead zone is one of the largest ever, and overlaps areas hit by oil from BP's broken Macondo well, they say. The "static kill" operation that began today is expected to permanently plug the well.

– Alabama is suing BP, Transocean, and Halliburton for “catastrophic harm” caused by the Gulf oil spill, the state’s attorney general announced today. The lawsuit, which names BP, Transocean, and Halliburton as defendants, seeks to recover damages for lost tourism, economic losses, medical expenses, and other damages, the New York Times reports. Alabama’s move comes after the White House released its final report on the spill.

– A huge blob of oil is washing up on the ocean floor of the Gulf of Mexico, and it could be there for a while, scientists say. The oil, which is believed to be from the BP spill, is at least 22 miles long and up to 5,000 feet deep in some places, according to the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, which has been keeping a close eye on it. "It's very, very large," a marine scientist at the University of South Florida tells the Los Angeles Times. "It's going to be in a very, very large area."

– Oil-eating microbes have been found in the Gulf of Mexico, but it's not the kind you'd expect. Instead, they feasted on a Manhattan-sized plume of oil released by BP's broken Macondo well, say scientists. The microbes were apparently stimulated by the spill, and they degraded the hydrocarbons so efficiently that the plume is now undetectable, reports Reuters.

– British lawmakers plan to grill outgoing BP CEO Tony Hayward over the Gulf oil spill next week as part of an investigation into risks surrounding deepwater drilling in the North Sea, Reuters reports. Meanwhile, BP said it will delay its third-quarter results due to the challenges of accounting for spill costs.

– BP's compensation plan for the Gulf oil spill probably won't cost the company as much as previously thought, analysts say. The company has set up a $20 billion independent claims fund, but claims probably won't top that, a Citigroup analyst said after a meeting with incoming CEO Bob Dudley. "Given current estimates of claims the $20 billion Independent Claim Fund established probably exceeds calls," the analyst said, according to Reuters.

– BP CEO Tony Hayward is taking heat from British lawmakers for his handling of the Gulf oil spill, but he's telling them it's not his fault. "It's been easy for some parties to suggest that this is a problem with BP," he told a parliamentary committee, according to Reuters. "It's been easy for some regulators to suggest that this is a problem with BP, but it's not my fault. It's the fault of the industry as a whole." He added that cost-cutting measures weren't responsible for the spill, and that the accident "highlights industry failings rather than flaws particular to BP."

– With a final shot of cement, BP permanently killed its deep-sea well in the Gulf of Mexico that ruptured in April and unleashed the worst oil spill in April and unleashed the worst oil spill in US history, Reuters reports. A remotely operated vehicle (ROV) working at the site of BP's Macondo well in the Gulf of Mexico captured the final shot and posted it online.

– The oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico will have “little or no effect on the medium-term outlook for offshore drilling and supplies,” the International Energy Agency tells Reuters. The IEA, an energy watchdog based in Paris, says the spill will have only a “limited impact” on the world’s energy supply.

– BP's incoming CEO Bob Dudley has promised a major overhaul of the company's operations in the wake of the Gulf oil spill, reports the Wall Street Journal. The head of exploration and production will be ousted, as will the head of exploration and production, who will take over as interim CEO until a permanent successor is named. “We’re going to have to restructure the company,” said Dudley. “We’re going to have to move faster.” In other BP news, Alabama says it expects to receive billions in penalties from the oil giant, notes Reuters.

– Cancer-causing chemicals have been found at "alarming" levels in the waters off the Louisiana coast affected by the Deepwater Horizon oil spill, according to a new study. Oregon State University researchers, who last sampled the area in August, say the levels of five carcinogens were higher than they've been since the spill began, the New York Times reports. The researchers, who say they're not sure whether the chemicals are the result of the oil or the dispersants, plan to conduct further tests in the coming weeks.

– The world's biggest-ever study of marine life has wrapped up, with 2,700 scientists from 80 nations finding more than 10,000 new species, reports the BBC. The $665 million 10-year study will help scientists assess threats to marine life from climate change to the BP oil spill, notes Reuters. Among the findings: A species of yeti crab never before seen in history, thought to have died out in the last Ice Age, turned up in deep waters for the first time. A 23-foot-long squid was discovered for the first time.

– The Obama administration was “overly optimistic” about BP’s ability to handle the Gulf oil spill, and relied too much on the company’s answers, according to an investigative panel’s report released today. The National Oil Spill Commission found that the administration relied too much on BP’s assurances that it would be able to handle the spill, and didn’t enough on information from BP itself, the Washington Post reports.

– Royal Dutch Shell's CEO is not happy with BP's independent report on the Gulf oil spill, calling it a "weighted report" that doesn't take into account Shell's design of the well, the Wall Street Journal reports. Peter Voser told an Oil and Money conference in London today that BP's report did not consider the thinking behind Shell's design of the well, which blew out, Reuters reports.

– BP has decided to waive the legal limit on its liability for the Gulf oil spill, a move that will allow it to pay workers' bonuses without having to worry about the cost of the disaster, the Wall Street Journal reports. The company had been under a legal cap on its liability under the Tort Claims Act, which limits liability tolimits set by Congress. BP said in a court filing that it had decided to waive the cap, which could have limited its liability to 75 million dollars plus clean-up costs.

– BP has agreed to set up a $20 billion escrow account to pay victims of the Gulf oil spill, reports the Atlanta Journal-Constitution. The oil giant will also set up a fund to pay victims of other disasters, such as the Indian Ocean oil spill and the Lehman Brothers collapse. The agreement with the Justice Department is expected to be announced today, notes the Journal-Constitution.

– BP's new CEO is taking a hard line on safety in his first public comments since taking the helm in the wake of the Gulf oil spill. Bob Dudley accused his rivals and the media of creating a "climate of fear" in the US during the spill, reports Reuters. "We're going to have to work harder to win back the trust of the American people," he said. "We're not going to succeed if we don't work harder. We're not going to succeed if we don't work harder. We're not going to succeed if we don't come up with solutions. We're not going to succeed if we don't come up with cost-effective solutions. We're not going to succeed if we don't have the ability to raise the money to pay for the spill." BP plans to sell up to $30 billion in assets to pay for the spill, notes the Wall Street Journal.

– Halliburton Co. used flawed cement in BP Plc's doomed Gulf of Mexico well, which could have contributed to the blowout that sparked the worst offshore oil spill in US history, according to documents obtained by the Wall Street Journal. The documents show that Halliburton tested the cement before drilling the well and found it to be flawed, even though it had been tested previously and found to be safe. BP used another type of cement, but it was also found to be flawed, according to documents obtained by the Journal.

– BP's third-quarter earnings beat analysts' estimates and the company raised its estimate of the cost of the Gulf oil spill to 40 billion dollars. The British oil giant's underlying profits, or earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation, and amortization, also beat expectations, the Wall Street Journal reports.

– The Coast Guard has taken the unusual step of allowing BP to suck up some of the oil leaking from the gushing well in the Gulf of Mexico, the Wall Street Journal reports. The move allows the oil giant to suck up as much of the oil as it can before a relief well can be completed, which could happen as soon as mid-November. BP has thus far managed to avoid the worst-case scenario of an uncontrolled gush of oil that could turn into the biggest oil spill in US history.

– The White House's oil spill commission presented its preliminary findings today, and they don't back up Bobby Jindal's claims in his new book, Politico reports. The commission found no evidence to support Jindal's claims that the largest offshore oil spill in US history was caused by the Obama administration's "lackadaisical" response to the Deepwater Horizon spill, according to a summary of the findings released by the White House.

– The Justice Department is set to release the results of its investigation into the BP oil spill today, and they're expected to show that the company made a host of mistakes that led to the biggest oil spill in US history, reports the Wall Street Journal. The Justice Department will also release the results of its own probe into the causes of the spill, and they're expected to show that BP and its partners made a host of errors in the lead-up to the spill, reports the New York Times. (Read the full report here.)

– The administrator of BP's $20 billion fund for victims of the worst oil spill in US history says it will set up a special fund for victims of other disasters, including the Boston Marathon bombing, reports the Houston Chronicle. Kenneth Feinberg, who was appointed by President Obama, says the fund will cover victims of all types, not just the oil spill. "This is not about BP," Feinberg tells the AP. "This is about the victims."

– BP's third-quarter loss widened as the oil giant set aside another $8 billion to cover the costs of the Gulf oil spill, but the company's shares rose as new CEO Bob Dudley said the company had turned the corner and would soon return to pumping out steadily rising dividends, the Wall Street Journal reports.

– The White House oil spill commission said today that BP told them the government's estimate of the amount of oil flowing from the Deepwater Horizon well was about 20% to 50% too high, reports the Wall Street Journal.

– BP's "breathtakingly inept" handling of the Gulf oil spill is finally coming to light, in the form of a scathing New York Times op-ed. In the piece, Michael Daly writes that the oil giant made "a series of decisions that were breathtakingly inept" in the immediate aftermath of the spill, and that his own company, Transocean, is taking the lead in cleanup efforts. "BP and its contractors made a series of decisions that were breathtakingly inept ahead of the largest offshore oil spill in US history," writes Daly, who accuses the company of a "colossal failure" in dealing with the spill. He calls for BP to be held accountable for the "colossal failure" and for the US to take the lead in cleanup efforts. Click here for Daly's full column.

– The Department of Homeland Security has issued a warning to Americans not to travel to parts of the Middle East, Turkey, and Iraq in the wake of last week's attack in Benghazi, Libya. DHS says travelers should avoid those areas for their own safety and that of others in the region, including Iraq, Syria, and Iran. "We strongly urge Americans not to travel there at this time," the department said in a statement. "In light of the tragic events in Libya, we strongly recommend that Americans avoid travel there at this time."

– The Dow Jones Industrial Average was down more than 100 points in the first minutes of trading following President Obama's victory in the midterm elections. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq were also down in early trading.

– The world's top three insurance brokers have teamed up to offer liability insurance for the massive oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico, Reuters reports. Munich Re, Aon Benfield, and Swiss Re have formed a consortium called SOSCover to offer insurance for the Deepwater Horizon oil spill, which is expected to be the biggest oil spill in history. Aon Benfield, one of the world's largest brokers of insurance for the energy industry, will manage the spill consortium.

– Stephen Baldwin and a friend are suing Kevin Costner, claiming the actor tricked them into selling their shares in a company that claimed to have developed a technology that would separate oil from water. Costner’s company, CINC, claimed to have developed a technology that separated oil from water. Baldwin and Spyridon Contogouris sold their shares in CINC, but say they were never told the company would be profiting from the technology, the Hollywood Reporter reports.

– The White House's long-awaited report on the Gulf oil spill is out, and it blames BP, TransOcean, and the federal government for most of the damage. The report doesn't assign blame, but it lays much of the blame on the companies involved, notes the Wall Street Journal. BP, for example, made "a series of cost-cutting decisions that ultimately contributed to the spill," says the report. TransOcean, on the other hand, made "irresponsible" decisions, says the report. Click here for more.

– In the wake of the BP oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico, a former employee of the oil giant has written an op-ed in the New York Times about her experience. Christine Bader, who worked for BP from 1999 to 2008 and is now a senior fellow at the Center for American Progress, says in her piece that she witnessed first-hand the "complete collapse" of the oil industry in the wake of the spill, which she calls "one of the most destructive events in the history of our country." She says that in the days after the spill, BP's top executives tried to cover up the fact that they had lied to Congress and to the public about the company's financial health. – The co-chairs of the White House oil spill commission made their case for legislation to prevent a repeat of last year's massive BP oil spill at two congressional hearings today. Democrats pressed for new legislation aimed at preventing a repeat of last year's massive BP oil spill, as Republicans warned that the disaster should not be used to hamper offshore oil and natural gas production. The renewed push to boost government oversight of offshore drilling came as the co-chairs of the White House oil spill commission, Bill Reilly and Bob Graham, made their case for legislation on the issue at two separate congressional hearings, the Wall Street Journal reports.

– A federal judge has ordered BP to explain why it took so long to stop the oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico, the AP reports. US District Court Judge James Robart said in his ruling that the government must explain why it took so long to stop the spill. He said the government has a right to know why it took so long to start cleaning up the oil. (Read the full ruling here.) The judge said the government must explain why it took so long to start cleaning up the oil. (Read the full ruling here.)

– The head of BP's exploration and production division will testify before a Senate panel today about the massive oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico—and he won't be defending the company's safety record. Lamar McKay will be joined by the president of Transocean, which owns the Deepwater Horizon drilling rig, and the CEO of Halliburton, which produced the infamous blowout preventer that failed to stop the spill, reports the Washington Post. Click here for more.

– A federal judge has ordered BP and other companies involved in the Gulf oil spill cleanup to hand over any documents related to the investigation to the Justice Department, the New Orleans Times-Picayune reports. The judge also ordered BP and other companies involved in the cleanup to hold off on releasing any documents until the feds finish their own investigation, which could take months. The Justice Department hasn't said whether it plans to do so.

– It could take two to four weeks to get a handle on the widening oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico, a Coast Guard official tells the New Orleans Times-Picayune. The Coast Guard has set up a command center in New Orleans, and experts are on the ground. BP, which owns the sunken rig, will take the lead on cleanup efforts, the official says. Meanwhile, Gov. Bobby Jindal has declared a state of emergency in Louisiana.

– The Coast Guard has told BP to intensify efforts to contain the massive oil spill near Louisiana, reports the Times-Picayune. Interior Secretary Ken Salazar met with the company’s top executives today and urged them to intensify their efforts to contain the oil, which began washing ashore late last night. Click here for more on the spill.

– BP's chief executive will testify before a Senate panel today about the massive oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico, reports the Los Angeles Times. Other execs will include TransOcean's CEO. Click here for more.

– BP's chief executive will testify before a Senate panel today about the massive oil spill and his company's preparedness for it, Politico reports. Other execs will include the head of Transocean, which owns the rig that blew out, and Cameron, which was involved in the drilling of the well. Click here for more.

– BP finally got some good news in the Gulf of Mexico in the form of siphoning some of the oil. A live video feed showed some of the oil being siphoned off the venting pipe, reports the New Orleans Times-Picayune. It's not clear how much of the oil is being captured, but it's a sign of progress, notes AP.

– The White House has announced the creation of an independent commission to investigate the Deepwater Horizon oil spill. Current and former federal officials will be excluded from the panel, which will be similar in scope to those that investigated the space shuttle Challenger explosion and the nuclear accident at Three Mile Island, reports the Washington Post. The announcement comes as BP continued to siphon some of the oil gushing from a damaged well on the Gulf floor but remained days away from trying to cap the leak. A tide of sludgy oil has begun washing into the fringes of Louisiana's coastal marshes, officials said today, as BP continued to siphon some of the oil gushing from a damaged well on the gulf floor but remained days away from trying to cap the leak. Watch the oil spill's path since May 2 and view how tourism, commerce and the coastline are all at risk.

– Workers combing the Gulf of Mexico for injured or dead wildlife have found a few injured animals, but officials fear that many more are dying as the oil spill spreads, the Washington Post reports. In a conference call with reporters today, officials from several federal agencies listed the animals injured so far Coast Guard Commandant Adm. Thad W. Thad W. Oil spill map: What's at stake? The agreement was the subject of a letter, obtained by the Washington Post, written by rig owner TransOcean and signed by a BP representative

– Interior Secretary Ken Salazar said yesterday that he was "angry and I am frustrated" that BP hadn't been able to seal its blown-out oil well in the Gulf of Mexico. "We are 33 days into this effort, and deadline after deadline has been missed," Salazar told reporters after visiting BP's U. Explore all of our oil spill graphics to track the spill, see its effects, and learn its possible solutions. Click here for more.

– Scientists aboard a University of South Florida research vessel discovered a large underwater plume of oil in the Gulf of Mexico, adding to fears that much of the BP oil spill's impact is hidden beneath the surface, reports the Times-Picayune. The scientists, aboard a University of South Florida research vessel, found an area of dissolved oil that is about six miles wide, and extends from the surface down to a depth of about 3,200 feet. The scientists, aboard a University of South Florida research vessel, found an area of dissolved oil that is about six miles wide, and extends from the surface down to a depth of about 3,200 feet, said Professor David Hollander Oil spill cleanup and containment efforts continue at the Gulf of Mexico site of the oil spill following the Deepwater Horizon explosion. BP engineers are pumping mud at a furious rate into the damaged blowout preventer that sits on the uncapped well at the bottom of the Gulf of Mexico today, as BP engineers armed with 50,000 barrels of dense mud and a fleet of robotic submarines are poised to attempt a "top kill" maneuver. Click here for more.

– Oil giant BP abandoned its "top kill" operation today after failing to halt the flow of oil into the Gulf of Mexico for a third day, reports the Washington Post. It's now expected to take at least a day to determine what caused the problem. Click here to read one columnist's take on why "environmental chic has driven us out there" in the first place.

– The Obama administration is taking steps to distance itself from BP and is dispatching Attorney General Eric Holder to monitor the Gulf oil spill, the Washington Post reports. Meanwhile, BP's CEO tells the Wall Street Journal that he doesn't know how much oil is being spilled, but that he's sure it won't affect his company's business.

– The White House has ordered BP to pay for five more large sections of Louisiana barrier island sand berms as efforts to contain the oil spill hit more obstacles and the slick approached Florida, the AP reports. The White House ordered BP to pay for construction of the berms as part of an effort to block the oil, which has already closed oyster beds, shut down shrimpers, and canceled fishing tournaments and panicked beach hotels from New Orleans to Key West. Click here for more on the spill.

– In the wake of the BP oil spill, one of the biggest environmental disasters in US history, scientists are calling for a ban on deepwater drilling in the Gulf of Mexico. Shallow-water drilling has long caused damage to coral reefs and other marine life, but deep-water drilling seems to have made the problem worse, the New York Times reports. The cause of the spill isn't yet clear, but scientists say it could take years to clean up—and the damage could be even worse if BP doesn't clean up its mess. "It's going to take a long time to clean up the oil," says a marine ecologist. "It's going to do a lot of damage to the coral reefs, and it's going to take a long time for them to recover."

– BP's stock price took a nosedive today as officials confirmed that the amount of oil spilling into the Gulf of Mexico is much more than the company had estimated. The stock price of BP plunged more than 15% today to a 14-year low, reports MarketWatch. "People forget that Sean Hannity was informing viewers of Barack Obama's radical ties" long before Glenn Beck hauled out a chalkboard, groused Crooks and Liars blogger John Amato.

– BP CEO Tony Hayward arrived at the White House today for a meeting with President Obama and other execs to discuss the Gulf oil spill, and the White House says the two will discuss the company's plan to set up a $20 billion escrow fund to pay spill-related claims. (Read the full letter here.) Also in attendance: Thad Allen, the Coast Guard official in charge of the spill cleanup. Click here for more.

– When BP CEO Tony Hayward appeared at the White House yesterday to apologize for the Gulf oil spill, it was “for the lost lives and environmental damage from his company’s doomed offshore rig,” writes Aaron Blake and Paul Kane of the Washington Post. “Perhaps no one in America knows this better than Kenneth Williams.” Williams is the head of Transocean, which owns the Deepwater Horizon rig. BP agreed yesterday to set up a $20 billion fund to pay spill claims, but it’s not clear how the money will be doled out. “Perhaps no one in America knows this better than Kenneth Williams,” writes Blake and Kane.

– Senior BP exec Kent Wells was grilled by federal investigators yesterday about the company's history of safety problems in the Gulf of Mexico and demanded more clarity on who at BP is ultimately responsible for the Gulf oil spill. Asked who had final responsibility for drilling work on the Deepwater Horizon, Wells replied, “I’m not aware of any one person at BP who is responsible for all of this.” The testimony came as BP announced a $20 billion fund to help Gulf Coast residents and businesses clean up the oil. BP has assembled a formidable team of Democrats for its Washington lobbying, legal and public relations offensive, the Los Angeles Times reports.

– The live video feed from BP's Deepwater Horizon oil well continues to show what appears to be huge amounts of oil pouring into the Gulf of Mexico, reports the Los Angeles Times. It's not clear how much oil is being spilled, but the live video feed shows a "firefight" between the company's engineers and the remotely operated vehicle they're using to control the well.

– Oil-spill victims who have received payments from BP will have to pay up on their taxes if they want to avoid penalties, the IRS says. Under current law, payments for lost wages are taxable—just as wages would have been, the IRS says. The IRS announcement comes as BP chief executive Bob Dudley made his first public appearance since the spill, notes the Times-Picayune.

– BP says it won’t make political contributions, “whether in cash or in kind, anywhere in the world. But BP North America—the energy giant’s U BP—declared in its corporate code of conduct that the company will not make political contributions in any country in the world,” the Washington Post reports. In fact, since the oil spill began, the company has donated $4,200 to political candidates and PACs in the US.

– As BP struggles to contain the massive oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico, one thing is certain: It's going to take a while to clean up. That's because there are so many factors at play, from the size of the spill to the amount of oil being spilled. Here's what you need to know about the spill, its effect on the US economy, and BP's plan to fix it: President Obama will meet with BP CEO Tony Hayward tomorrow to go over the plan, which involves pumping mud into the gushing well through a tube, reports the New York Times. It's not clear whether the plan will work, but Obama has said he wants to know whether it will work before he signs off on it. BP's current strategy is to pump in heavy mud to plug the well, but it's not clear whether that will work. It's not clear whether the plan will work on the surface, where the oil is more easily accessible. Click here for more.

– Oil sheen and tar balls have made their way to Lake Pontchartrain, a major source of drinking water for New Orleans, but experts say the oil isn't likely to cause major environmental damage, the New Orleans Times-Picayune reports. Lake Pontchartrain is a major source of fresh water for the city, and the presence of the oil sheen and tar balls is a "psychological blow," says a local environmental activist.

– BP removed the containment cap on its gushing oil well today in an effort to speed up the rate at which oil is being captured, reports the AP. It's not clear whether the move will work, but if it does it will speed up the rate at which oil is being captured, perhaps more than doubled from the current rate of around 5,000 barrels a day. It could be 24 hours or more before engineers know whether the cap change will work, notes the New Orleans Times-Picayune. Tropical Storm Lee, due to hit the Gulf tomorrow, could delay the plan another 24 hours.

– BP put in a new containment cap over its gushing oil well in the Gulf of Mexico today, but it may not be able to stop all the oil until at least tomorrow, reports the Washington Post. Ken Salazar issued a new moratorium on new permits for deep-water drilling today in an effort to get around an injunction issued by a New Orleans federal judge.

– SpongeBob SquarePants and his friends in Bikini Bottom have a message for the BP contractors, cleanup crews, and news media that have descended on this small beach town where oil washes up almost daily, notes the Federal Eye: "We want BP contractors, cleanup crews, and news media to know that we are with them in Grand Isle, La., and we are not going anywhere." Click here for more.

– A live video feed of BP's latest attempt to contain the oil in the Gulf of Mexico didn't work, and officials decided to keep it closed for at least 24 more hours as they assess the situation, reports the New Orleans Times-Picayune. Meanwhile, attorneys for crew members of the Deepwater Horizon oil rig told a federal panel investigating the accident that things could have been done differently in the hours before the explosion, reports the Wall Street Journal. They accused the Obama administration of trying to pin the blame on BP instead of cleaning up the mess.

– A photo posted to BP's Facebook page appears to show the oil giant's CEO shaking hands with a woman who looks like Hillary Clinton. But it's not clear if the woman in the photo is actually BP's CEO, Tony Hayward, or if the woman in the photo is one of BP's employees. Bloggers have identified three BP images posted this week that appear to have been altered using photo editing software, according to BP's Facebook page.

– The Coast Guard has ordered BP to evacuate the area surrounding its ruptured oil well in the Gulf of Mexico ahead of Tropical Storm Bonnie, reports the Times-Picayune of New Orleans. Hundreds of workers and more than a dozen vessels will begin moving from the site today, stopping work on the long-awaited final kill of the well for more than a week. The decision to begin the evacuation was made late yesterday by retired Coast Guard Adm Hearings focus on possible human factors in BP oil spill hearings focus on possible human factors in BP oil spill. A former chief electronics technician on the Deepwater Horizon oil rig testified yesterday that an alarm system designed to automatically alert the crew and prevent combustible gases from reaching potential sources of ignition had been deliberately disabled.

– Chemical dispersants sprayed into the Gulf of Mexico to break up the massive oil spill do not appear to threaten the safety of seafood in the affected waters, the Food and Drug Administration said this week. In a letter sent in response to questions from Rep. Peter King, the Obama administration has announced that three—fours of the oil that leaked into the Gulf of Mexico from BP's Macondo well is contained— evaporated, skimmed, collected, burned off, dispersed or dissolved.

– Looks like BP's new CEO will be Robert Dudley. The company's board is expected to announce the choice this morning, according to the Wall Street Journal. Dudley would replace gaffe-prone Tony Hayward, who was ousted last month. The 55-year-old was responsible for overseeing the company's response to the Gulf oil spill, according to the Journal's sources.

– If all goes according to plan, the "static kill" operation could begin as soon as tonight, the Los Angeles Times reports. That would involve pumping mud into the gushing well to plug it, followed by cement to seal it. It's not clear whether that will work, but if it does, BP will have to wait at least 24 hours for the results of that procedure.

– BP finished pumping cement into the blown-out Macondo well in the Gulf of Mexico as part of its efforts to permanently plug the source of the nation's worst oil spill, the company said today. Engineers started cementing the operation at 10:15, reports the New Orleans Times-Picayune. It will take at least 24 hours to seal the well. Click here for more.

– The gooey oil fouling the Gulf of Mexico is taking a heavy toll on the Gulf region's economy and people's lives. In Grand Isle, La., for instance, the gooey mess is already taking a toll on the local economy and people's health, reports the Times-Picayune. Oil from the sunken Deepwater Horizon rig is washing ashore as early as this week and could take up to a month to clean. In Plaquemines Parish, La., one of the hardest-hit areas, the spill is already taking a toll on the local economy and people's health. – TransOcean fired off a scathing letter to BP yesterday, accusing the oil giant of hoarding information and test results related to the Deepwater Horizon blowout. TransOcean fired off a scathing letter accusing BP of hoarding information and test results related to the Deepwater Horizon blowout that killed 11 people, including nine TransOcean employees. Meanwhile, New Orleans Mayor Mitch Landrieu told the National Press Club yesterday that it will take another five years for the city's recovery to fully recover from the BP oil spill.

– Federal investigators grilled BP senior VP Kent Wells yesterday about the company’s history of safety problems in the Gulf of Mexico and demanded more clarity on who at the company is ultimately responsible. Investigators cited a 2003 letter to Wells from the federal Minerals Management Service that blasted BP for—among other things—incomplete planning, poor communication, insufficient knowledge or training, and a lack of effective supervision. Click here for more.

– BP says it has spent more than $5 million a week on advertising since the Gulf Coast oil spill—more than three times the amount it spent on ads during the same period last year. BP told the House Energy and Commerce Committee that it spent a total of 93 million on advertising from April to the end of July, and that it expects to spend another $30 million in the near future, reports the Washington Post.

– BP's internal report on the Gulf oil spill doesn't mince words: It blames the US government, Congress, the oil industry, and the public for the mess, reports the Wall Street Journal. “The US government, Congress, the oil industry, and the public have all been grossly negligent in their response to the oil spill,” says the report, obtained by the Journal. “In particular, the US government has been unable to contain the oil spill quickly enough.”

– The results of BP's internal investigation into the Deepwater Horizon oil spill are in, and they don't appear to show that the company cut corners to save money, the chief investigator said yesterday. “My view is that we did n't see any indications that we did n't see any indications that support that,” said Mark Bly, who added that the investigation found no evidence that BP had tried to save money by cutting corners. BP released its report this week and insisted it was not trying to pin the blame for the disaster on anyone. But that's not how it reads today in the Los Angeles Times, which calls the report "a start, but wait for other probes to get answers." Click here for more.

– A federal judge has ordered BP to hold off on drilling the well responsible for the massive oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico until state officials can figure out how to clean up the mess, the AP reports. The judge also ordered the oil giant to hold off on drilling the well until the state can figure out how to clean up the mess itself, which could take months.

– BP has agreed to join forces with Exxon, Chevron, Royal Dutch Shell, and ConocoPhillips in the event of an oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico, the New Orleans Times-Picayune reports. They'll each spend $1 billion to create equipment and train teams in case of a future spill.

– New BP CEO Bob Dudley has shaken up the company's senior management team in the wake of the Gulf oil spill. Dudley, an American, has ousted the company's chief of exploration and production and divided his responsibilities among three other BP executives, the Wall Street Journal reports. He will formally take over Friday. In other news, the chairmen of the president's Oil Spill Commission expressed skepticism Monday about claims from BP and government officials that initial underestimation of the flow rate of the Macondo well had no impact on the response to the spill. “It’s a little bit like Custer Spill panel presses BP on response plan,” one chairman said.

– Thad W. Allen can finally retire now. The Thad W. Allen Show aired its final episode last night, and it was a doozy. First, there was the death of Thad W. Allen's mother. Second, there was the death of Thad W. Allen's twin sister. Third, there was the death of Thad W. Allen's brother-in-law. Last but not least, there was the death of Thad W. Allen's best friend.

– President Obama's National Commission on the BP Deepwater Horizon Oil Spill and Offshore Drilling released four working papers today saying the administration's response was marked by confusion about the spill rate, slowing federal effort immediately after the oil exploration well blew out April 20 and creating the impression that it was either "not fully competent" or "not fully candid with the American people about the scope of the problem," reports the New Orleans Times-Picayune.

– In his weekly radio address, President Obama laid out his vision for America's energy future—and it's not exactly clear how he's going to get there. "We're going to create millions of new jobs," he said. "But we're also going to make sure that our energy security is as secure as it can be. That's why I'm calling on Congress to pass legislation to make our dependence on foreign oil a thing of the past." (The full text of his plan can be seen here.) The president also laid out his vision for climate change—and it's not exactly clear how he's going to get there. "We're going to have to make tough decisions, but we're going to do it based on science," he said. "We're not going to let science dictate what we do. We're going to make sure that our energy security is as secure as it can be." (The full text of his plan can be seen here.) – BP's latest attempt to contain the oil leaking into the Gulf of Mexico ran into technical obstacles over the weekend that increased the likelihood of a prolonged battle to stop the leak, reports the Times-Picayune. BP's effort to contain the oil leaking into the Gulf ran into technical obstacles over the weekend that increased the likelihood of a prolonged battle to stop the leak. Click here for more.

– Bill Clinton has arrived in Port-au-Prince to offer his help in the aftermath of the Haitian earthquake. The former president, who is currently the UN special envoy to the country, met with Haitian President Jean-Bertrand Aristide and other officials today, the AP reports. Clinton also plans to visit a Port-au-Prince hospital where he says he has seen "bodies all over the place," the BBC reports. He's expected to visit a field hospital where survivors are being treated. In other developments: Wyclef Jean has called on fans to donate to relief efforts. "Your money will help with relief efforts," he tweeted. Former member of the Fugees, Pras Michel, whose parents are Haitian, has also called the quake a "tragedy."

– The death toll from last week's earthquake in Haiti now stands at 100,000, according to the country's president, who says the real toll is closer to 200,000. But that's still a far cry from the government's own estimate of 300,000 dead, and aid workers warn that the real toll is likely to be in the hundreds of thousands. "There are tens of thousands of children who have been orphaned," the director of a Haiti children's shelter tells the BBC. "It's going to be a long process to reunite them with their parents."

– Relief workers in Haiti are still struggling to get food, water, and medical assistance to survivors as the death toll from the country's devastating earthquake rises to at least 200,000. "There are no hospitals in Port-au-Prince," a doctor with Medecins Sans Frontieres tells the BBC, warning that as many as 20,000 people who could have been saved by surgery may die every day as they are buried in the rubble. The death toll is expected to rise as workers reach the more remote parts of the country. "People are sleeping everywhere because they are too afraid to stay inside their houses," a relief worker in Port-au-Prince tells the BBC. "There is no food, no water, no electricity."
